business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Minchin, representing the Minister for Sport and Tourism. Does the government agree with an IOC Athletes' Commission plan to have all athletes carry doping passports requiring them to be available for out of competition testing at any time? Will the minister for sport be backing this proposal for Sydney 2000 at her drug summit, or does the government favour White House drug adviser Barry McCaffrey's push for a totally independent drug testing agency?
âI cannot put my hands on a brief on that question so I will take it on notice and get an answer to the senator as soon as possible.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question that the minister can perhaps tackle. Can the minister confirm that the Australian Olympic Committee has refused to attend the government's proposed international drug summit later this year in an official capacity and may only attend as an observer? Isn't this so-called drug summit simply a grandstanding exercise to cover up for the minister for sport's inability to take effective action against drugs in sport, including her failure to attend the IOC drug summit earlier this year?

âThat is rather a tiresome accusation against the excellent work being done by the minister for sport, Jackie Kelly. This is going to be an extremely successful summit on drugs in sport. It is being attended by countries around the world. They are enthusiastic about attending this international drugs in sport summit. Australia is regarded as a world leader in the fight against drugs in sport, and I note that representatives from Olympic committees in a number of countries will be attending the summit as part of their country's delegations.
âMy question is to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Justice and Customs. Will the minister inform the Senate of the success of the Australian Federal Police Overseas Liaison Network?

âI thank Senator McGauran for his question. The Federal Police Overseas Liaison Network currently comprises 29 agents operating in 17 posts in 16 countries. The relationship between the Federal Police liaison officers and overseas law enforcement agencies is growing and provides a very sound basis for continuing operational successes.

answer.para: The government's commitment to strengthening the Federal Police's international links is paying dividends. I am delighted to be able to inform the Senate that yesterday in Sydney the Australian Federal Police arrested a major international fugitive from justice. This man was indicted in the United States for his role in the importation and distribution of 180 kilos of cocaine into the United States in 1990, and conspiracy to import and distribute 2.5 tonnes of cocaine between 1989 and 1992. The arrest of this major crime figure stemmed from Federal Police investigations into the activities of a Sydney-based syndicate of South American nationals. The investigations resulted in seizures of large quantities of cocaine, heroin and cash as well as the arrests of several people within Australia, Germany, Italy and the United States.

His arrest and the success of Federal Police investigations is just another fine example of international police cooperation and the effectiveness of the Federal Police Overseas Liaison Network. The end result is that the good work of the Federal Police has helped break a large international drug syndicate.

But this is not the first time that the overseas networks have located a fugitive from another country. As the Senate will recall, in November 1998 the Federal Police located and arrested Carlos Cabal Peniche who was wanted by the Mexican government for an alleged $600 million fraud. But, as the Demtel person says, `Wait, there's more.' The AFP successes over the past year also include contributing to the arrest of dozens of suspects and the seizure of hundreds of kilos of illicit drugs in countries other than Australia. Just as we receive intelligence from overseas countries that help us with our drug busts, so we contribute back to the international pool of intelligence. We have contributed to successes in Thailand, Hong Kong, Canada, Papua New Guinea and Japan. The AFP's efforts in these cases have had considerable significance in the creation and success of cooperative law enforcement networks in our region.

Of course, the drug seizures and other operational activities do not complete the picture of cooperative assistance in the Pacific region, which is important in the fight against transnational criminal activity, which then directly impacts on Australians. Success also comes from a cooperative approach to law enforcement training and the exchange of ideas and personnel, and that is reflected in the Federal Police's work in Vietnam, Vanuatu, the Solomon Islands, Papua New Guinea, Thailand, Singapore and China. The government recognises that work of the Federal Police and was very pleased to commit additional funding in May 1999 of roughly a third of a million dollars to expand that network. It is an excellent return from a strategic investment.
I was very pleased in April to attend the opening of the Federal Police liaison post in Vietnam and to be present in China at the first appointment of a Federal Police liaison officer in Beijing.

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Newman, representing the Minister for Defence. How serious is the breakdown in the relationship between the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Minister for Defence, Mr Moore, which is reported on the front page of the Financial Review today? Is it true that the factors contributing to the breakdown are the minister's sacking of his former secretary, Mr Barratt, the choice of Mr Barratt's successor, and a proposal by Mr Moore for a meeting of defence ministers in Darwin? Whose version of events are we to believeâthat being put about by Mr Moore-Wilton or the one being put about by those who are backgrounding on the defence minister's behalf?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âAs a representative of the Minister for Defence, I have no intention of adding to the scuttlebutt that is being put about by members of the Labor Party. I would caution the ALP, the opposition, to not believe what they read in the newspapers.
âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would have thought that a senior minister of the government, representing the Minister for Defence, could have providedâ
âMadam President, I raise a point of order. It cannot possibly be relevant to any supplementary question to know what Senator Faulkner's thoughts on any matter might be.
âSenator Faulkner has had six seconds and I would ask him to come to his question.

âWhat I was asking, before I was so rudely interrupted by Senator Alston, was this: given the importance of a good working relationship between the defence minister and the country's senior bureaucratâthe head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinetâat such a critical time, can the minister reassure the Senate that the report in today's Financial Review is entirely without foundation?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI repeat the answer I gave at first. I caution the ALP not to believe the scuttlebutt that is in the paper.
âAnswer the question.
âI am answering the question in the way that I choose toâa question which you asked.
âOrder! Senator Newman has the call to answer the question and opposition senators should stop shouting.
âI have answered the question, Madam President.

âMy question is directed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Will the Assistant Treasurer advise the Senate of the significance of recent APRA superannuation assets figures, which showed that total superannuation assets in Australia topped $400 billion for the first time ever in 1998-99? Will he also inform the Senate what effect the government's proposed changes to business taxation will have on superannuation?

âI thank Senator Watson for that very important question. Senator Watson has a longstanding interest in superannuation and it comes as no surprise that he is pursuing this matter in the chamber today. The superannuation system, as we all know, plays a key role in helping Australians enjoy higher living standards in their retirement. I have great pleasure in informing the senator today that the superannuation savings of Australians continue to grow very strongly. In fact, as Senator Watson said, the recent figures from APRA show that superannuation assets in Australia reached over $400 billion in June 1999. This is a growth of some 14 per cent in the year to June. Contributions ended the year some 39.5 per cent higher than the year before, increasing from some $33.9 billion to $47.3 billion.

answer.para: Australians are now contributing almost $1 billion a week into their superannuation. Both voluntary member contributions and employer contributions, under the superannuation guarantee, are showing strong growth. Retail funds, industry funds, corporate funds and self-managed funds all shared in the growth. I think we are seeing very strong confidence in superannuation. Madam President, you may recall that some years ago when superannuation was being debated in this chamber there were comments from the other sideâand Senator Sherry in particularâthat people lacked confidence in superannuation.

talk.start.para: âThe SGâthe superannuation guarantee. It is Labor policy.

âSenator Sherry, on one remarkable occasion, came into this chamber and indicated that he had spoken to his hairdresserâwho I think was Barry, Bruce, Johann or Stefanâand said that this particular gentleman lacked confidence in superannuation, and so Senator Sherry lacked confidence in superannuation. Fortunately, the Australian public do not lack confidence in superannuation. That is whyâ
âGo out and ask them.
â`Go out and ask them,' says Senator Sherry. You went out and asked Bruce. Bruce gave you an answer and Bruce was wrong.

answer.para: The second part of Senator Watson's question related to the business tax reforms. It will be well-known that, as part of the capital gains tax reforms, only two-thirds of capital gains will now be taxed, effectively meaning a rate cut from 15 to 10 per cent. This move, I think, has been very widely welcomed by the superannuation industry. The Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia hailed the Ralph report as positive and balanced. The Investment and Financial Services AssociationâIFSA, as it is often knownâsaid that the business tax reforms would greatly enhance the capacity of the economy to produce improved savings and investment rules.

It is the coalition government that is cutting capital gains tax on superannuation fundsâremembering, of course, that it was the Labor Party that imposed the tax in the first place. The government not only wants to cut the CGT on superannuation but also wishes to give people choice and control over their superannuation. This is another important policy from the government which will further improve superannuation in this country.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Hill, representing the Prime Minister. Is the minister aware of the recent scaremongering comments by the royalist Senator Minchin, attempting to raise community fears about the fate of crown land under a republic? Has the Howard government sought any authoritative advice on this matter, and can the leader assure the Senate and the Australian community that the position of crown land would be calmly and properly dealt with by the states? Does a republic threaten the position of crown land in this country?

âIn the circumstances, I think I will adopt the Senator Mark Bishop defence. This morning he said, `Why are you asking me silly, irrelevant and futile questions?' I am not aware of Senator Minchin's contribution, but I know that he is out there supporting the monarchist side. I am supporting the republican side and I hope that my side gets up.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. It is quite obvious that Senator Hill has not taken this question seriously. The question of crown land is indeed a serious matter. I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: why does the Prime Minister only directly take action in the referendum debate to stifle republican coalition members from promoting the yes case, yet allow rabid royalists like Senator Minchin to make outrageous, inflammatory and misleading statements, and to do so at will? When will the Prime Minister actually take seriously his public commitment to remain neutral on the referendum, instead of using his surrogates to take the running on the royalist cause and to do so in an inflammatory way?
âThat has only the slenderest connection to the question or the answer, but if Senator Hill has anything to offer, I will give him the opportunity to do so.

âRepeating what I said yesterday, there is a misunderstanding. The Prime Minister actually barracks for the monarchist side. What he is doing is ensuring that the Australian people have the opportunity to vote for an alternative.

answer.para: Senator Bolkus interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Bolkus, I call you to order.

âWhat he is ensuring is that the Australian people have the opportunity to vote for an alternativeâthat is, an Australian as head of state. I welcome the opportunity for Australians to have a chance to move forward in that way.

subdebateinfo.title: Business Tax Reform: Capital Gains Tax

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Does the Assistant Treasurer agree that the capital gains tax cut is not fully funded? Is the minister aware that if the `extra realisations' figure is excluded from the funding of the tax cut, as the most recent official American research suggests, then the capital gains tax cut could be unfunded by up to $2 billion? Is the government prepared to revisit its capital gains tax cut to ensure that it is fully funded without relying on some selective and over-optimistic United States economic theories, thereby ensuring that the tax is fair and not regarded as a gift to the rich?

âThe tax is fair. The capital gains tax measures have, I think, been widely welcomed. To the extent that there is confusion, it is confusion over the Labor Party's position on this matter. You would have thought that the Labor Party could have at least come to some policy position on the Ralph report. The truth of the matter is that they find it exceedingly hard to do so.

answer.para: It is true that Australia currently taxes capital gains comparatively harshly compared with many other countries. I think most of us in this chamber would agree with that. Ralph estimates that the proposed CGT reforms will be revenue positive, notwithstanding the reduction in the CGT rate. I point out to Senator Murray that overseas experience supports the conclusion that a lower CGT rate increases realisations. As I think I pointed out in this chamber before, it reduces the lock-in effectâthat is, the reluctance of some people to sell because of taxâit encourages capital formation and will make Australia more competitive. A relatively strong short-term positive revenue response is expected to follow the lowering of the CGT rate. In the first two years, the Ralph review estimatedâI do not think anyone has questioned the integrity of Mr Ralph and his colleaguesâ

talk.start.para: âNo, just the study.

âSenator Conroy may have, but of course he questions the integrity of everybody around this place. Apart from Senator Conroy, there is no doubt about the integrity of Mr Ralph and his colleagues. In the first two years, the review estimated a 50 per cent increase in the rate of realisations as investors realigned portfolios due to the CGT rate cut and the revenue gains from increased realisations more than offset revenue losses from the lower rate. The Ralph estimates are not inconsistent with the findings reported in the study commissioned by the ASX.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! I point out to opposition senators that, if they wish to debate this topic, there is an appropriate time to do it after question time but not during the answer to the question.

âThe estimates in the Ralph report are not inconsistent with the findings in a study commissioned by the ASX. There is a very extensive discussion on this in the Ralph report and, if people wish to pursue this topic, I think there would be some merit in reading that discussion. The government has accepted the findings in the Ralph review.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I have read the Ralph discussion on CGT and regret to confess I am still confused. Is the minister aware that the charities and churches sector has today labelled the capital gains tax as unfair? Is the minister aware that tax experts like Professor Rick Kreever, Professor Chris Evans and the Taxation Institute have raised concerns about the lower, unfunded capital gains tax creating new tax avoidance loopholes? Can the minister provide an absolute assurance to this chamber that a lower capital gains tax will not open up things like the pre-1985 bottom-of-the-harbour schemes that allowed high income earners to unfairly reduce their tax burden?

âWe believe that the tax is fair. We believe that in adopting the proposal of the Ralph Committee we are bringing in a fairer tax system, a system that encourages investment, encourages savings and would therefore ultimately lead to the creation of jobs and a better functioning economy. We believe that the tax system is fair; we believe that there are in the Ralph review a range of measures in relation to tax avoidance; we believe those measures are effective and important. The government is very conscious that people pay their fair share of tax, and I do not think there is any doubt about the government's commitment to this. Certainly, the previous government was very lax in the tax avoidance area and has been rightly criticised in this chamber by me and others for its performance. But Senator Murray should have no doubt about the commitment of this government to make sure that people pay their fair share of tax.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Car Industry

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Minchin. In light of the minister's unbelievable denial yesterday that there are any serious demand problems for the Australian car industry, is the minister aware that motor vehicle registrations for August 1999 are at their lowest level since August 1997? Does the minister agree that one of the primary reasons for this decline is a GST inspired buyers' strike? In light of this, is the minister aware of any government reviewâexpected or currently under wayâexamining the impact of the GST on the car industry prior to 30 June 2000?

âThe opposition seems to be drying up. This is almost exactly the same question as I had yesterday, and I will give the same answer. The fact is that 1998 was the record year for Australian car sales. It was the biggest year ever, under our government, with sales of 807,000 units. That followed the 1997 year, which was also a record year for car sales. We had two record years in a row. It is not surprising that, after the incredible sales figures of those two years, there has been some fall-off. I said yesterday that in the year to Septemberâthat is, looking at the nine months of 1999 to Septemberâsales are down 2.9 per cent from the same period in 1998. But they are 11 per cent higher than they were in 1997, which was the second biggest year on record. If this continues, this year is likely to be the second biggest year on record for car sales. At worst, it will be the third highest year for car sales ever in Australia. So to say that they are the worst since two years ago is really a fiction.
âOrder! Senators talking across the chamber are out of order.

âIt is only two years, and 1997 was itself a record year. Sales are running ahead of 1997, and 1998 was an outstanding year for the car industry. We congratulate them on that. There has been a downturn. It is 2.9 per cent lower this year than at the same time in 1998. It is not clear that the marginal downturn is a direct function of buyer anticipation of lower prices under a GST. We are in close consultation with the industry. From the very start of this process, we have undertaken to consult with them closely to keep the matter under constant review. We are watching it very carefully, but we do not want the car industry to suffer.

answer.para: What you have to remember is that we are talking about a product which will be considerably cheaper as a result of our tax reforms, and we are being attacked on this by an opposition that actually wants to keep the sales tax on cars high. You want to keep the 22 per cent sales tax on cars. As I said last night, your record on this is an absolute disgrace. In 1992 you dropped the tax on cars from 20 per cent to 15 per cent simply to match our promise of a 15 per cent GST. As soon as you got back, in 1993, you engaged in the most cynical act ever seen when you increased the sales tax on cars to 22 per cent. You did not put it back to 20 per cent; you went even further and put it up to 22 per cent. Where was the compassion for the car workers then? You did not care about the consumers of cars then when you did that. You put car workers out of work because of what you did to the price of cars, so don't come in here lecturing us because we are about to lower the price of motor vehicles.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it from the minister's answer that the government is actually conducting a review. Could the minister inform the Senate when the results of the review will be announced?

âThe government, through the relevant departments, is working closely with the industry to keep car sales under constant review. It is a constant process of examining car sales on a regular basis. We are talking to the companies about their forward orders so that we have as clear a picture as possible of what the automotive situation is like. It is an ongoing, constant review, and we will act if necessary.

âMy question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. Mrs Eileen Nixon has leased and operated Shelburne Station for 31 years, utilising environmentally responsible techniques including sweet water, natural pasture and organic roads programs, and the implementation of a property management program. Will the minister inform the Senate of the federal government's preferred course of action in relation to the management of the Shelburne Bay area, given the environmental sensitivity of the area?

âI thank the honourable senator for the question. Shelburne is, as most senators will know, to the north-east of Cape York. It is a pastoral lease and is also an area of exceptional natural beauty and, I think I can say, rare beauty.

answer.para: Senator Schacht interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âThe north-east area of Cape York. I am sorry that these geographical issues might be difficult for Senator Schacht.
âSenator Hill, ignore the interjections.

âThe honourable senator will be aware that this property has been recognised for a long time as ideal for inclusion within the national reserve system because of its exceptional national beauty, as has the adjoining property to the south, that of Bromley. The property was leased, and I understand that the lease has now expired. I gather that there is some dispute between the Nixon family and the Queensland government as to whether the Nixons have rights upon expiry. No doubt that will be determined through processes in Queensland.

answer.para: Consistent with what I have just said, our attitude as a government is that we would like to see these properties within the National Reserve System. That does not necessarily mean that they need to be held by governments. Our attitude has been that the reserve system should encompass not only assets that are held by governmentsâthe most traditional form was national parksâbut also assets that are held under tenure by other parties such as non-government organisations or individuals who are prepared to commit the assets for their conservation value for the benefit of the total community. In some circumstances where individuals have been prepared to do that, we as a government have supported those individuals in that objective because we recognise that in some instances it is at a cost to them and it is a cost they are paying for the benefit of the total community.

We do not have a firm view on the best form of tenure for these properties, but we are strongly of the view that they would be wonderful assets within our National Reserve System. We are very much committed to the concept of a comprehensive and representative reserve system across Australia that reflects the broad and unique ecosystems with which we have been blessed. We have helped fund the development of the National Reserve System through the Natural Heritage Trust. For the benefit of the honourable senator, I stress that we have made those payments only on a voluntary basis; we have not funded compulsory acquisitions. We see the building up of the National Reserve System as being on a voluntary basis.

I hope that sheds some light on our attitude to these matters. I believe that one of the Nixons still lives on the property. Our attitude in relation to individuals who obviously have a very strong bond to these properties, whether the leases have expired or not, is that they should be treated sensitively. As I understand it, Mr Nixon, who still remains on the property, is elderly. I would have thought that some arrangement could be entered into that might allow him to remain on the property and perhaps assist government in its responsibility to conserve the natural assets for the benefit of the total community.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Senator, for clarifying that position. Is the minister aware that Mick Hayes of the Stock Squad, two plain-clothes police officers and a gentleman named Mr Mick Barrat have at this present moment entered Shelburne Station and the Nixon's home without providing a reason for their visit and have not produced identification to Mrs Nixon? Would the minister inquire as to the purpose of the visit?

âI will make inquiries of the Queensland government. I repeat what I said a moment ago. Whether a lease has expired or not, I think elderly people who have lived on the property for a very long period and obviously have a very strong bond with the property should be treated sensitively.

âMy question is to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Has the minister received representations from the Taxation Institute of Australia expressing its view that the 1996 cut in the R&D tax concession from 150 per cent to 125 per cent has meant, in its words:

para.inline: Significant R&D projects have either been abandoned or deferred and Australia's relative attractiveness as an R&D centre has diminished.

question.para: Is the minister aware that, according to the authoritative Rogers and Feeney 1999 R&D Scoreboard, 18 of the top 20 companies in terms of R&D intensity, including cutting edge companies such as Cochlear, Resmed and OzEmail, reduced their R&D effort this year? Why will the government not act to stop the serious decline in R&D in Australia?

talk.start.para: âExpenditure on R&D under this government is actually higher than it ever was in any full year under the Labor government. It is true that in 1995-96 expenditure on R&D increased dramatically. We know, and Labor admitted this in its changes that it mooted in late 1995, that that was a result of runaway expenditure under the R&D syndication scheme, which was being significantly rorted and which Labor itself admitted had to be changed. While changes were mooted by Labor, we acted in our first budget to clamp down on the rorting of the syndication. We keep getting lectures from the opposition about all this. It did nothing about syndication during its term of government.

answer.para: Senator Cook interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator Cook, you can debate the matter at the appropriate time.

âWe did something about syndication: we got rid of it. Also, because we were left with a $10,000 million annual deficit, a debt for the nation approaching $100 billionâan increase of $70 billion in Labor's last five yearsâwe had to do something about government expenditure. It was very important to us to ensure that the burden of reducing that deficit was shared right across the board. We were not going to make sure that it was just workers who had to bear that burden; business had to bear that burden as well. That meant that, as a responsible government, we had to reduce the tax concessions for R&D from 150 per cent to 125 per cent, which was a saving to the revenue of $300 million.

answer.para: We keep getting lectured by this mob about putting it back up to 150 per cent. They never tell us where the $300 million is going to come from. We are being lectured about the Ralph reforms and being told that they must be revenue neutral, but they never tell us where they are going to find the $300 million to put the R&D concession back up to 150 per cent. Of course we would like to provide more incentives for R&D, but R&D is at what are otherwise record levels. It has fallen off from those peaks that occurred in 1996-97 and 1997-98. Expenditure in 1997-98 was down about four per cent. But what the opposition fail to recognise is that we have had the lowest commodity prices for the mining industry since 1800. A large proportion of R&D conducted by business in this country is conducted by the mining industry. Obviously and inevitably mining industry expenditure on R&D has fallen quite significantly because they are facing the lowest real commodity prices since 1800.

talk.start.para: âWhere was the mining industry in Australia in 1800, Nick?
âYou would not know anything about the mining industry, Senator Schacht. Just wait till Senator Bolkus sends you out to Makin.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! There are far too many senators persistently interjecting, and I am noting that you are doing so.

âThe 125 per cent tax concession remains a commitment of this government, and it remains a substantial and considerable concession to encourage R&D. I also point out the significant encouragement to R&D that will occur as a result of the implementation of the Ralph reforms, through both the reduction in the company tax rate, providing greater after tax dollars for investment in R&D, and significant cuts in the capital gains tax. The entry of pension fund moneys from the US into venture capital moneys will be a significant boost to R&D, as many commentators in this industry have said.
âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister also aware that the Taxation Institute of Australia has said:

para.inline: I wish to express our concern that the recommendations of the Review of Business Taxation to reduce the corporate tax rate to 34% and then 30% will dilute the benefits of the R&D tax concession.

question.para: Does the minister accept this analysis, and if not, why not?

talk.start.para: âThis really is an absolutely and utterly hypocritical proposition being put to us by Labor. When the former Labor government reduced the corporate tax rate in 1988 from 49 per cent to 39 per cent they made absolutely no adjustment to the R&D tax concession. And what happened to R&D? It actually went up as a result of that cut in the tax rate. In 1993, Labor again reduced the corporate tax rate, from 39 per cent to 33 per centâand again it made absolutely no adjustment in the R&D tax concession at that timeâand at that time R&D actually went up after that reduction in the corporate tax rate. We are very confident that that history will be repeated when we reduce the corporate tax rate to 30 per cent.

answer.para: Senator Cook interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Cook, I invite you to read standing order No. 203 and reflect upon what it says.

âMy question is directed to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. There have been many misleading comments and press articles recently about the funding of women's organisations. I therefore ask the minister whether she would be kind enough to inform the senators as to how government funding of such organisations ensures that there is a broad range of input into women's policy?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI am very pleased to be able to speak about our new approach to the national women's NGO funding programs, because this approach will foster a professional, representative and influential women's sector. All applications for funding for women's organisations for national secretariat purposes were assessed on selection criteria made explicit through a public tender process. The three successful organisations which I announced provided an impressive range of activities, extensive affiliations, active input into policy processes and detailed plans to deliver quality secretariat services over the next three years. For the first time ever, women in Australia know that there are three key bodies who are well supported to represent their interests to government. The funding to these organisations has been doubledâ

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senators on my left will cease interjecting. You are in breach of the standing orders.

âThe funding to these organisations has been doubled to $100,000 a year. These organisations are all very robust, vibrant, well-established and national women's NGOs with involvement in a wide range of issues relevant to a very broad range of women. I draw your attention to the fact that for women's organisations to be funded on a triennial basis means that they have certainty as to their funding and they have the ability to plan to take on staff and to become even more professional than they are now.

answer.para: The YWCA, the National Council of Women of Australia and the Australian Federation of Business and Professional Women will be required to abide by the same standards as the rest of the community sectorâstandards that the taxpayer would expect. Anyone who knows these organisations would be well aware that they do not always agree with the government. Indeed, most of the peak organisations funded through different portfolios speak out strongly.

I would like to remind the Senate that this was a very rigorous process and it followed consultations and workshops with women's organisations all around the country over a number of months of the first part of this year. We have not defunded women's organisations. We have maintained a minimumâ
Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder!

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âMadam President, they would like to shout me down, but the facts defy their dishonesty, and I am afraid that the informationâ

âOrder! Senators on my left should abide by the standing orders and stop persistently shouting during the answer to a question. There is an appropriate time to debate the matter if you have a difference of opinion.

âThere are in fact now two rounds of funding for women's organisations through the Office of the Status of Women and there is a further round of funding through the mainline departments. The first round of funding has been announced, and the second round of funding is now in processâit is now in the assessment phase. I will shortly be announcing a further round of project grants for women's organisations to undertake projects which advance the status of women or strengthen their organisation. These projects will be assessed similarly to the previous round, by competitive merit against selection criteria. The two tranches of funding will bring the total funding for women's organisations' activities through OSW to well over $500,000. We agreed to requests from organisations to delay this second round to give them more time to prepare their submissions.

question.para: Our strategy to assist organisations which provide services to women includes not only the OSW funding but also the encouragement of other portfolios to fund specific issues women's groups. Last year an extra $350,000 was received by women's organisations from other Commonwealth areas. Those organisations that performed well in the secretariat tender process, but whose focus is more portfolio specific, I have referred to my colleagues to consider for further attention. This in fact has occurred with my announcement today of funding for the National Council of Single Mothers and Their Children, which will be funded by my own department, through the Department of Family and Community Services. Our government has delivered considerable benefits for Australian women, and I would like to have the opportunity to say some more. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I must say it has been very difficult to hear Senator Newman's answer because of the number of interjections from the other side. Therefore, I would like to ask Minister Newman if she would further elaborate on the strategies that have been undertaken and also what other consultative activities have been initiated by her.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âLet me make it quite clear: in 1998-99 this government overall has provided women's groups with more than $850,000 in funding from OSW and other agencies. That includes $50,000 to women's sportâ

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senators on my left are in breach of standing order 203 in persistently, and I believe wilfully, interjecting.

âI understand the sisterhood do not like these facts getting put on the public record. As I said, $50,000 to women's sport, funding from the Office of Disability to support Women with Disabilities Australia and funding to rural women's groups through the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry.

answer.para: When you look at the government's record in providing a sound economic environment, low interest rates for women for their home purchases, new women's health initiatives, especially for rural womenâ
Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I raise a point of order. I would ask you to remind senators on the other side of what you have been telling them about five times while Senator Newman has been speaking, that they have been constantly interjecting. I cannot hear what she is saying.
âSenators on my left know, I believe, that they are behaving in a disorderly fashion.

âI would like to conclude my summing up of the government's record for women, which is a very good one. There have been improvements in superannuation for women, which the previous government ignored for years and years, and a real breakthrough on prevention and early intervention on domestic violence so that we do not just accept that it can go on forever. We are committed to achieving more. (Time expired)

âMy question is to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Minister, what action have you taken to ensure that the proposed selling off of BHP's Whyalla facilities does not jeopardise any of the 2,000 direct jobs relying on those works or any of the many more jobs in the Whyalla community which indirectly depend on BHP's presence?

âI thank Senator Schacht for this question and wish him well in his campaign in Makin. BHP has been keeping us closely informed of its plans in relation to its steel assets, and we appreciate very much the way in which BHP has been keeping the government properly informed. I have said on behalf of the government that we appreciate that cooperation. We understand BHP's rationalisation of its assets, that it has decided that its future lies essentially as a minerals company with some steel assets and that that is a good direction for BHP and will make BHP a stronger company. We are reassured by BHP that these sales will not result in any plant closures. They will be sold as going businesses. They will not close any plants. The chairman of BHP Steel has given that assurance repeatedly and it is one that I think the community can accept. We are being kept closely informed and will work with BHP as it rationalises its assets.

answer.para: I am very pleased that the people of Whyalla have reacted very positively to the announcement by BHP. I think this does mean that there is potentially an even brighter future for the steel assets in BHP and for the steel industry in Whyalla. I look forward to those assets being purchased by a company or interests that have a real commitment to the Australian steel industry, that will make a very big contribution and a big investment towards a real future for Whyalla. As I say, the very positive reaction from the people of Whyalla has been terrific. We are working with the state government, and the state government with the company and the community, to ensure that there is a real future for those assets and for that company in Whyalla.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, BHP have stated that they will not close the works if they cannot sell it. What guarantees has the government sought from BHP that they will not allow the works to run down by not reinvesting in modernising or updating the plant, which will be needed in the immediate future, such as approximately $90 million for the relining of the blast furnace at Whyalla by no later than 2005? In view of the response from the Whyalla community being, as you say, positive, do you have any plans to visit Whyalla, or are you more interested in supporting Camilla as the next Queen of Australia?
âIgnore the last part of the question, Senator.

âSenator Schacht purports to come in here and express some concern and sympathy for BHP workers and for the community of Whyalla but completely debases his question by a cheap little shot about a very important public issue which we are all facing. The ALP have said they are going to devote all their resources to campaigning for a republic. That is their right and I am not going to criticise them for that. They have actually said they are not going to do any policy development or announce any policies until after this referendum is over. So you completely debase your question. We are concerned about the people of Whyalla. We want to have a bright future for them in their steel industry. You have completely cheapened your shot by your ridiculous assertion.

âMy question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. The minister recently announced that he would not be withholding money from the Natural Heritage Trust for the Bushcare Revegetation Program in Queensland. This is despite, as the minister would be aware, recent satellite data which shows that the already staggeringly high rate of land clearing in Queensland has jumped in the last two years by another 18 per cent across the whole state, with a 55 per cent increase on freehold land alone. Moreover, the minister will no doubt be familiar with the performance indicators in the national vegetation initiative document, which include bringing the rate of habitat destruction below the rate of revegetation and that there be no clearing of endangered ecosystems. Given that Queensland meets neither of these key criteria, why has the minister decided not to withhold the relevant NHT funds from Queensland until such time as the criteria are met? Why is the government providing funds when trees are being cut down and land cleared yet is not providing funds for the South-East Queensland Regional Forest Agreement, which is stopping native forest being cleared?

âYes, we are supporting through the Natural Heritage Trust programs of revegetation and protecting remnant vegetation, and we think that is an important public investment. We are also, in a comple mentary way, seeking to encourage the states to provide effective land clearing regimes in order that clearing takes place only on a broadacre basis where it is sustainable in ecological terms and does not include clearing that will have a detrimental effect upon endangered or threatened species or ecological communities. So it is true that there are two sides to this ledger. On the one hand, we are trying to retain native vegetation through support programs and, on the other hand, we are trying to encourage states to play their part, as having a primary responsibility for natural resource management in this country, to achieve better results as well. And it is true that the Queensland government has signed up to complying with that obligation, both in terms of land clearing controls and protecting threatened and endangered species.

answer.para: The argument that I think the honourable senator is putting to me is: shouldn't you refrain from supporting the revegetation programs whilst overclearing is still occurring? The downside to thatâthe contrary argument to thatâis, firstly, that you would be missing opportunities to support good revegetation programs, and that is not in the national interest. Secondly, you would be missing opportunities to support good natural resource managersâgood farmersâwho are acting responsibly in relation to their land, and that is not in the national interest either. So I have not really seen the matter as an either/or one. I want to see us achieving better outcomes on both sides of the ledger; that is, in revegetation and in protecting, through better and more effective clearing regimes, Australia's native vegetation.

It is worth recalling that overclearing in Australia has cost this nation a great deal, both in economic terms and in ecological terms, and out of that we should at least be learning from the mistakes of the past. Overclearing is not good in terms of providing a healthy natural system for future commercial gain and it is not good in terms of loss of biodiversity, which in many cases will never be replaced.

So, having acknowledged the principle that we have overcleared, that we should learn from the mistakes in the past, that over clearing where it is still existing today should be countered and that better practices should be in place, the response of this government is then to work constructively with landholders and state governments to achieve those goals. In terms of the fact that clearing rates around Australia are reducing, we are achieving some success but I say that with a recognition that in some parts of AustraliaâQueensland being oneâoverclearing is still occurring, and we want to see better results.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the minister's quite accurate comments about the damage done by land clearing, I would be interested to know what form of pressure he is bringing to bear on the Queensland government to ensure that in my home state, where land clearing is still increasing, that situation changes. Given that the minister has also made a firm commitment to keep the nation's emissions of greenhouse gases to no more than eight per cent above 1990 levels, in accordance with the Kyoto protocol, and that the ongoing land clearing in Queensland contributes about 10 per cent of Australia's CO2 discharge, what support will the Commonwealth give the Queensland government in terms of putting together an effective on-farm conservation incentive package to assist the Queensland governmentâin the constructive manner that the minister is talking aboutâto effectively halt the clearing of Queensland's endangered as well as threatened ecosystems on freehold land, which together add up to some 4.25 million hectares of my home state's most threatened vegetation?

âBriefly, most Australian states instituted clearing controlâminimum regulatory environmentsâwithout any Commonwealth support at all. Therefore you could argue that for the Commonwealth now to come in and support the Queensland government in doing what it should be doing in any event is inequitable compared to the other states.

answer.para: On the other hand, I recognise, because of the extent of the issue in Queensland, that some Commonwealth support could constructively help achieve a better outcome, and that is the message that I have given to the Queensland government. But it has to take the lead because it is primarily responsible for natural resource management in Queensland. When it demonstrates that lead and comes to us and asks if we can support it in achieving better outcomesâbetter outcomes for the land-holder, better outcomes for the communityâthen, as we have indicated, we are prepared to work positively and constructively with it towards that goal.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: New and Second-Hand Cars

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Does the minister recall telling the Senate yesterday that, while cars will be a lot cheaper after the GST for new car buyers, `I would say that buyers do need to take account of the changeover price'? Was this just a subtle way of admitting that, while new cars will be cheaper, buyers trading in their existing car can expect to get substantially less on their trade-in, potentially wiping out the gains made from the cheaper new car? What does the minister believe will be the effect of the introduction of the GST on the trade-in value of second-hand cars?

âThe real point is that Labor wants more expensive cars, we want cheaper cars. Both second-hand cars and new cars will be cheaper under this government. Australian workers and consumers will be much better off under this government when the tax changes come into effect on 1 July 2000.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware that the Motor Trade Association of Western Australia has produced figures which show that, after the introduction of the GST, a new Corolla will be $2,208 cheaper but the trade-in value of a second-hand Corolla will be lowered by $2,000? Doesn't this mean that a person wanting to upgrade their Corolla after the GST will save only $208 on a car valued at $24,538? Why has it taken this minister so long to finally admit that many new car buyers will basically gain nothing out of the introduction of the GST?

âThose figures mean that the people that the Labor Party purports to represent, the low income earners of Australia, will have access to cheaper second-hand cars and cheaper new cars. We thought that was something that you might support, but clearly you do not.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Family and Community Services and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, Senator Jocelyn Newman. The Howard government has a strong commitment to maintaining a fair and sustainable social safety net for those in the community in genuine need. Can the minister please inform the Senate of any further developments regarding the first ever green paper on welfare dependency?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to announce today the terms of reference for the development of that first ever green paper on welfare dependency for Australia. The terms of reference include: the development of options for change to income support arrangements, aimed at preventing and reducing welfare dependency for those of work force age; and options relating to the provision of associated services, including employment, education and training, that will assist in preventing and reducing welfare dependency. In providing this advice, the reference group will give particular consideration to the broader application of mutual obligation, demographic changes, sustainability of the current system, the particular incentive effects associated with the design of social security payments for people of work force age and international best practice.

answer.para: The reference group will draw on community input and provide me with a preliminary draft paper early in the year 2000, with the final paper to be provided to me by 30 June 2000. On the issue of the discussion paper, I regret that I am not in a position to give any discussion paper to the Senate today. It is still being developed as the government's submission to the reference group, and it will be completed shortly. As soon as it is complete, I shall give it to the reference group, and I am happy to give it to the Senate at the same time. I am not opposed to an open and transparent policy making processâquite the contrary, as I made clear in my speech to the National Press Club and I also made clear to the Senate a couple of weeks ago. In fact, it is difficult to think of a more transparent process than a green paper developed out of public submissions, published with an invitation for further public debate. I now table the terms of reference for the green paper reference group.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

âSenator Lundy asked me a question in question time about drugs in sport, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Sport and Tourism. I seek leave to incorporate my answer in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as followsâ
. The Government and the Minister the Hon Jackie Kelly have on the Communities concerns regarding drugs in sport.
. For example, in May of this year, she launched the Tough on Drugs in Sport strategy which clearly spells out a comprehensive set of measures to combat doping in sport.

. Reducing the illicit supply of drugs banned in sport is a key element of the strategy and the Government is already acting in this area. For example, on 13 September 1999, Senator Vanstone announced tough new restrictions on the import of EPO. Importation of EPO is now prohibited, except via permit.

. In addition, the Ministerial Council on Drugs Strategy and the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General are currently looking at penalties across all jurisdictions, on the illicit manufacturing and trafficking of anabolic steroids.
. Also, the Australian Customs Service has deployed a range of strategies to combat the importation of prohibited drugs in Australia ahead of the Sydney 2000 Games.

. The reason that almost 30 countries are enthusiastic about attending the International Drugs in Sport summit is that Australia is regarded as a world leader in the fight against drugs in sport. It is interesting to note that representatives from the Olympic Committees in a number of countries will be attending the summit as part of their country's delegation.
. The OAC has advised they have an issue about the appropriateness of attending as part of a Government delegation.
. They want to preserve their independence.
. The Federal Government has issued an invitation for the AOC to attend as part of a national team.
. I commend the initiative of Jackie Kelly in organising this international summit.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âOn 30 September, Senator Stott Despoja asked me a question about irradiated food. I undertook to obtain further information from the minister, and I have obtained that. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as followsâ

SENATOR STOTT DESPOJA âMy question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Aged Care. I am wondering if the Minister is aware that the Australia New Zealand Food Authority's own fact sheet states:

. . . it is not always possible to detect an irradiated ingredient when it is a component of a large food product or ifâfor exampleâan irradiated spice is blended with a large volume of non irradiated spice.

Given this, how does ANZFA intend to implement its recommendations endorsed at the August health ministers meeting to label all irradiated foods when detection is so difficult? And can the government really guarantee that all irradiated foods will be labelled, if irradiated ingredients are present and undetectable in the food supply?
SENATOR HERRON âThe Minister for Health and Aged Care has provided the following additional information in answer to the honourable senator's question.

Labelling of irradiated foods or irradiated ingredients will need to comply with the current regulations in the Food Standards Code , not to do so will put a food manufacturer in breach of the States and Territory food laws and the Fair Trading Acts.
It is illegal to sell irradiated food in Australia. The new standard requires a case-by-case approval of any product to which ionising radiation may be applied.

All irradiated foods, no matter how minor the ingredients, will be labelled, and approval will be subject to a demonstrated technological need. Applicants must also show that irradiation would not be used as a substitute for good manufacturing and food hygiene processes.
Manufacturers will know that their ingredients have been treated by irradiation because of the approval process.
If a manufacturer knows the product to be free of irradiated material there will be no requirement to so label the product but it may be so labelled.

SENATOR STOTT DESPOJA âMadam President. I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his response in particular, his recognition that there is a distinction between cooking of the food through irradiation procedures and actually sterilising the food and therefore there is a health issue for consumers. I acknowledge the minister's comments in the relation to keeping consumers informed, but I must ask the minister: Given your concern about informing consumers about what they are eating, why is it that the health minister did not include, in their post-meeting communique, the decision to lift the 10-year moratorium on irradiated foods? Why was that not open to the public and the media? Is this just another issue like that of cadmium in peanuts, which was snuck through without proper debate while everyone else was focusing on the gene food decision?
SENATOR HERRON âThe Minister for Health and Aged Care has provided the following additional information in answer to the honourable senator's question.

The Australia New Zealand Food Standards Council (ANZFSC), which consists of the New Zealand and State and Territory Health Ministers and is chaired by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Senator Grant Tambling, met on 3 August 1999. At the conclusion of the meeting, ANZFSC issued a communique about the meeting particularly describing the issue of the labelling of genetically modified foods. The communique also noted that the Council had considered strict control on food irradiation, food safety standards and cadmium in peanuts.

It was the view of Health Ministers at the meeting that the media and public would in the first instance only be interested in the topical agenda item dealing with the labelling of genetically modified food.
The other issues are complex and a detailed information package on all these issues was subsequently prepared, issued to the media and placed on ANZFA's website on 6 August 1999.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources (Senator Minchin) to a question without notice asked by Senator Schacht today, relating to the operations of BHP in Whyalla.

Today I asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources what the government was doing, in conjunction with BHP, to guarantee the future of the steel industry in Whyalla, South Australia's biggest regional town. Whyalla is a town in which over 2,000 people are employed by BHP, with many hundredsâif not thousandsâmore employed indirectly because of BHP's steel industry there. The minister answered that he has had some discussions; he is confident that BHP will find a buyer for the steelworks and that the industry will continue. BHP have indicated that if they do not find an appropriate buyer, they would not close the works. But when I asked whether the government has sought any guarantee from BHP that they would not allow the works to wind down, that they would make the necessary reinvestment in equipment to keep it as a modern plant, the minister made no response. The minister has given no indication that he is willing to go directly to Whyalla and talk to the local community, as well as BHP, and be involved in ensuring that that community is given first-hand contact with the government.

When the announcement was made by BHP last week that it was selling the Whyalla steelworks, the main interest that the minister for industry had was a major speech he gave to the Australian constitutional monarchists defending the present system. And what an extraordinary speech he made! I wish he would make as vigorous a speech in ensuring that the 2,000 workers at BHP in Whyalla had a future, as he did in defending the present system of Australia, the constitutional monarchy. It is extraordinary, Mr Acting Deputy President, that in this said speech, delivered last week, Senator Minchin spent a large amount of the time directly attacking and abusing the campaign director of the Australian Republican Movement, Mr Barnes. Mr Barnes, Senator Minchin recognises, was a former coalition stafferâas I understand it, senior adviser to the Minister for Finance and Administration. Senator Minchin described a former colleague's senior staffer in his own government as a `republican bully'. To quote Senator Minchin:
I didn't spend two years of my life helping Trish Draper win Makin from Labor just to have this republican bully give the seat back to Labor as the price of his perverse version of a republic.

That is an extraordinary attack by this industry minister on a former senior staffer of his own government. It shows where this minister's real interest is. It is not in the industry portfolio; it is off defending the present Constitution of Australia, which has the Queen of Australia as our head of state. In this amazing speech that the minister makes, he is more interested in trying to redefine the Governor-General as the constitutional head of Australia. He is not the head of Australia. The minister tries to support the myth that the Governor-General is the head of state in Australia, not the Queen, to save him the embarrassment of having to defend the Queen.

As a senator from South Australia and as the industry minister, Senator Minchin should be paramount in ensuring that South Australia's largest regional town has a long-term future in the steel industry. He has done nothing so far to indicate that he has other than a marginal passing interest in the future of Whyalla. One would have thought the industry minister would have been up-front, dealing publicly with BHP and seeking their assurances about the future of the works. Advice I have been given is that, in the next few years, the steelworks at Whyalla have to have significant reinvestment in new equipment to maintain it as a modern steel plant. For example, by 2005 the main blast furnace will have to be relined. That is estimated to cost around $90 million.

Even if BHP do not sell the works, what commitment will we have from BHP that they will not allow the works to just dwindle away and disappear? Or if they do sell the works to another companyâmaybe a foreign companyâwhat guarantee has the minister sought that the buyer will have a caveat on their purchase that they will not just dispense with the asset, dismantle it and sell it for scrap, or shift the works offshore? These are the issues people in Whyalla are absolutely keen to get answers about. They have reacted positively in the hope that they can keep their steelworks under a new owner. But this minister is doing nothing to assist them in that long-term optimism that they have a future. This minister is more interested in defending the constitutional monarchy of Australia by denying that the Queen is our head of state. In doing so, he is out there abusing his former staff members and the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Costello. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThat was a most curious speech from Senator Schacht. He started talking about the steel industry and then we found ourselves wandering off around the monarchy issue. Fortunately, he did come back to Whyalla at the end. I think this shows the cynicism of the speech that we have just heard from Senator Schacht, and I think it shows that he does not really care about the steel industry. He has just brought up this issue today to score a cheap political point.

speech.para: Let us go back to the real issue at the centre of this. The real issue relates to what BHP have done with the steel industry. This is a matter very close to my heart, being from the Hunter Valley, and I have been following BHP's actions on this very closely over the last few years. As a matter of fact, I was a member of a special task force set up by the former minister for industry, Mr Moore, and I have actually crawled through every steelworks in Australia, along with people like Allan Morris and other members of a wideranging cross-party committee. During those many days looking at the steel plants at Whyalla, at Newcastle and at other places around Australia, we spoke to a whole range of people in the steel industry. From that set of hearings, we appreciate first-hand the problems presented by such a complex issue in the current international trading environment.

Let us have a look at that bottom line, because steel prices are at a historic low. We have had problems right across the last few years, with the slowdown in the Asian economy and with the dumping of steel from the USSR, which have created very unfavourable market conditions. Despite all that, we have had over recent years an excellent performance from BHP, but they do have an enormous problem with the state of the steel assets in certain parts of their business. If you go back to the key area of their business, and that is the Port Kembla plant, that plant has been rejuvenated over the last 15 years. It is now the third most efficient integrated steelworks in the world, and it has a great future with follow-on products, with coatings such as Colorbond and with the things you can do with flat products.

The problem BHP have is in the Long Products Division. They have made a commercial decision. This is not a decision for government; this is an adjustment within BHP. They have decided to refocus their business into a narrower range of products, in particular in the natural resources area. Of course when BHP started, at the end of last century, they were a natural resource producer. They did diversify into steel and they are not getting out of steel. They are refocusing and staying in part of steel, and they propose to sell off their other assets.

I would have thought the ALP would actually welcome such a move. Here is the party which over the last 70 or 80 years have been railing against monopoly production of steel in this country with BHP, and here we have a proposed divestment where other firms can come in and produce in steel and of course go through a process of competition, which I thought the ALP would welcome. It is a great pity that BHP did make this commercial decision, from our point of view. Perhaps they could have stayed in long products steel, but they have made a commercial decision, which any firm can make. That decision has been welcomed by people like Kevin Maher, who is the head of the ironworkers in Newcastle. He made the point that if BHP are not committed to rod and bar type production and do not want to stay in that part of the business, they have a right to move on. He would welcome another player who would be prepared to put more money into that area and create some competition in the steel business. So I would have thought that the ALP, who have been against monopoly capitalism for all these years, would actually welcome this move. BHP have the right to make this decision. It is not really the role of government to tell businesses the way in which they should develop their business, what sorts of things they should focus on, and whether they should divest or not divest. This government actually supports BHP in making that commercial decision. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am a bit concerned this afternoon. I certainly support what Senator Schacht said about Whyalla and, indeed, some of the other questions this afternoon to Senator Minchin, but I am somewhat concerned. I think Senator Minchin is not quite the same Senator Minchin that we had 12 months ago. I remember Senator Minchin in here, day in and day out, talking on the native title dispute and in the debates that went through this place on two separate occasions which I think spanned 100 hours. He sat there cool, calm and collected through the whole exercise. He just seems to be so agitated today. He is a bit like a cat on a hot tin roof. In fact, we asked him a series of what we thought were fairly reasonable and sensible questions. I asked him one about the trade-in value of cars. I would have thought that he could have answered that one in any one of a number of different ways. Before anyone wants to jump up, the steel for those cars came from Whyalla. At the end of the day, straight up and down, he was asked a simple question about it. What did he do? He got up and was just plain cranky. He took one minute, did not answer the question and sat down.
âHe lost it.

âAs Senator Mackay says, he just plain lost it. This is not the Senator Minchin whom we are accustomed to and, some would say, loveânot all, but some would say love. On this side, he is quite popular. But over there, he is not so popular. In fact, a few of them were chasing him out of the chamber a minute ago. I saw Senator Hill wanting him to get out of there. He almost had to drag him out by the legs, you know. He just would not leave the chamber, because he knew that we were going to say nice things about him. At the end of the day, we really have to ask what has happened in the last 12 months to poor old Senator Minchin. Unfortunately, I think this monarchy stuff is really getting to him. I really have to say that. All the interjections that have been made on this side about what Camilla would give a tick to and what she would not give a tick toâits not true. Its Prince Charles who has been his mentor over all these years. I can tell the Senate here and now that Prince Charlesâ
âCome on, Quirkie, get back to the steel industry.
âHe has been to Whyalla, too.

âMr Acting Deputy President, I seek your guidance on a point of order. Is it within standing orders for a senator to attack the character of another when that senator has been plotting with another on his side, Senator Bolkus, to unseat Senator Schacht and therefore comes to the debate without clean hands? In those circumstances, isn't this unjustified attack out of order?
âThere is no point of order, Senator Hill.

âIt is a pity there was not a point of order. I could in fact have answered that point of order very well. Senator Hill should have been listening to this debate. I fully supported Senator Schacht in this debate today because he raised a very important point that matters to South Australians, with the exception of members of the Liberal Partyânamely, Whyalla. We care about Whyalla. We care about those 2,000 workers out there and it is not good enough to say that, as the minister said here today, `They're going to get looked after; we've got some vague promises from the company.' Well that company gave a few promises to a few thousand other workers around the placeâ

speech.para: Senator Murphy interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIt may well be that Senator Tierney, who has more experience of crawling through steel plantsâ

speech.para: Senator Murphy interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator, he is not a bad fellow, really. He is trying to do his best, crawling through the boardrooms and all the rest of it, but at the end of the day he may know more about it than we do. But we are genuinely concerned about what is happening at Whyalla. What did we get from Senator Minchin? We got a very uncharacteristic approach from him. What we got was just cranky. He is losing it, and he is certainly not looking like the threat to Senator Hill that we thought he was a couple of months ago. Senator Hill worries, obviously, about senators knifing other senators.
âI am worried about Senator Schacht.

âIndeed! We are worried about you, Senator Hill. On the basis of today's performance, I can tell the Senate that Senator Minchin is going to have to go back and confront some of these issues and, somehow or other, take it a bit easier because, at this stage, he is not ready to take over Senator Hill's job here in the chamber. He is not there yet.
âGive Schachty a fair go.

âWe will, Senator; we always do. I have supported fully his motion to take note of Senator Minchin's answer. You should support him as well. Whyalla is important to all South Australians, including you. Can you go and have a quiet word with Senator Minchin and tell him to take it just a little easier.

âWell, I have heard just about everything. When I heard Senator Quirke get up and say in his opening statement, `I support Senator Schacht,' I really did a double take, because it is true that Senator Quirke has never supported Senator Schacht for anything. I must say that Senator Schacht really drew the short straw today when he was the first to have to get up and raise the issue of Whyalla and the steelworks because, in fact, Senator Schacht is not that concerned about Whyalla or the steelworks or jobs. Just right now there is only one job that is important in South Australia to Senator Schacht: his own job. His good friend and colleague Senator Bolkus, who sits alongside him, quite publicly in South Australia says that Senator Schacht has been in the Senate too long and that it is time he moved on. You are lucky that you came here a bit later, Senator Quirke, because your good friend Senator Bolkus and you have been able to come to some accommodation. But I do not know what that makes Senator Bolkus, because he has been here six years longer than Senator Schacht. So if Senator Schacht has been here too long, I do not know how much longer Senator Bolkus thinks he should stay here before he has been here too long.

speech.para: We saw Senator Schacht get up and raise the issue of Whyalla and the steelworks. I have to say that it was one of the worst preselection speeches I have ever heard. If he has to convince his preselectors in South Australia, or should I say if he has to convince Senator Bolkus and Senator Quirke because they actually conduct the preselections in South Australiaâ

talk.start.para: âYou'll never convince them; its all a plot.

âI know he will never convince them. It is all a ploy, but Senator Schacht tried valiantly to justify his own position in taking note of answers today under the very small pretence of being concerned about the steelworkers at Whyalla and what is happening in Whyalla in relation to BHP's sale of their steelworks in that city.

speech.para: Senator Bolkus and Senator Schacht both chose to leaveâthey are possibly out sorting something out without you, Senator Quirke, so I would be careful if I were you. The people of Whyalla have welcomed this move. Senator Schacht never mentioned that. The people of Whyalla welcomed BHP's decision to put their steelworks on the market, because they think they would have a better future if the steelworks were bought by somebody else and there is a change of strategic direction. Senator Schacht is not speaking on behalf of the people of Whyalla or the workers of Whyalla, because those people themselves want the sale to go ahead.

Senator Schacht, on the pretence of raising an issue of jobs and Whyalla and steelworkers, wanted to talk about other matters, such as the proposed referendum on 6 November. Incidentally, unlike the Labor Party, people on our side have a free choice as to which way they will vote and who they will support. Senator Hill and I happen to be on opposite sides of the fence, but it does not make any difference to our contributions to the real substance of what is happening in this chamberâand neither does it to Senator Minchin. Unlike the Labor Party, Senator Minchin has the capacity for work that some of them could only dream about, and he is able to do all of the work that is required of his portfolio.

talk.start.para: âWhy can't the Labor Party cope with a touch of democracy?

âNo democracy. I did make a note about that, Senator Hill. I said that I do not know why, when we have a free vote. The Labor Party, with their historic in-built prejudices are a party that hates democracy. It is the worst thing because they could not arrange little jobs on people like Senator Schacht if they had a true democracy. Senator Quirke would realise that. The former deputy leader of the state parliament in South Australia, Mr Ralph Clarkeâone of Senator Quirke's former close friendsâknows all about democracy. The Labor Party performed so well in South Australia that one of their own not only took them to court but also got the court to agree with him that he was right. The Labor Party sitting opposite us have no idea of what democracy means and will not give their own a free vote, like we happen to do in the Liberal Party. We have a free vote on this particular issue, and always have had.
âIt's a tragedy what has happened to the once great Labor Party.

âSenator Hill, I am a couple of years older than you, and even I cannot remember `a once great Labor Party'. I would love to be able to, because I know there was a time when they actually had some principles and stood by them. But, unfortunatelyâeven at the tender age of 56, which I reached the other dayâI never knew that once great Labor Party which fought only for the worker and for workers' conditions, instead of getting themselves involved in every other matter that they could conceivably become involved in. (Time expired)
