âI want the Senate to take note of the answer Senator Minchin gave to my question today in respect of the effect of the downturn in car sales on the car manufacturing industry in Australia and on the general car industry.

âMr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. As I understood it, Senator Schacht said he wanted the Senate to take note of Senator Minchin's answers on Whyalla and the steelworks. I think you should put that question before Senator Murphy starts talking about the car industry, which is a totally different question and a totally different issue.
âI am sure Senator Murphy is coming to the point.

âIt is the same matter, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will talk about the steel industry and the car industry all in one. We will put the steel in the car and we will try to put a bit of steel in your minister to make sure he can stand up for the car industry. Yesterday, Senator Minchin came in here and would have us believe that there was some record amount of cars sold. He said:

speech.para: The facts relating to car salesâ
which are made of steel, some of it coming from Whyallaâ
are that 807,000 cars were sold last year . . .

For the average punter, a car is a passenger vehicle that you get in and drive. That is what people would generally accept. Senator Minchin was very liberalâin fact, bordering on misleading the Senateâin his statement yesterday about 807,000 cars. It is simply not true. He went on to say:
. . . for three-quarters of this year, sales are down 2.9 per cent . . .
That is true in respect of total vehicle sales only.

talk.start.para: âMr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order.
âSo we don't want to hear the truth?

âMy point of order is that it was clarified at the start that Senator Schacht asked the Senate to take note of Senator Minchin's answer to a question in relation to Whyalla and the steel industry. Senator Murphy probably has the wrong set of notes, because I think he was going to refer it back to steel and the steel industry, but he has not done so in his time thus far. He then said that perhaps some Whyalla steel was used in motor cars, but in fact it is not. Somehow or other he should be drawn back to the subjectâwhich is steel, jobs and Whyallaâand he should make his answer relevant.

âMr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I distinctly recall the contribution that Senator Ferguson made just a few minutes ago. I hardly recall him referring to the steel industry at Whyalla when he was talking about the Labor Party and preselection processes, so I would suggest that there is no point of order on Senator Ferguson's behalf. In fact, I am talking about the car industry, which also is related to the steel industry at Whyalla.
âThere is no point of order. Senator Murphy's contribution to date has been well within the practice of relevance so far in this debate.

âThe truth is obviously hurting Senator Ferguson, and it is obviously hurting his colleague Senator Minchin, who has almost misled the Senate either inadvertently or deliberately. He said that 807,000 cars were sold last year and claims it as a record. It is simply not true. If we look at VFACTSâwhich I assume Senator Minchin would get as the relevant industry ministerâfor the year, only 407,544 passenger vehicles were sold, which is down by 6.2 per cent.

speech.para: That is the relevant question here. That is the point that you as a government have to address with regard to the car industry of this country. It is not as though you have not known about this.

Another misleading statement that Senator Minchin made in response to a question from my colleague Senator Quirke was in regard to the price of cars. Somehow the government, when it was proposing to introduce a GST, wanted people to believe that there was a major benefit in car prices. We know there are statementsâand I think Senator Quirke quoted one of themâbut one which I find interesting refers to a Commodore Executive. Of course, there may be some benefit for those people who can buy top end of the market cars, but if you look at the actual value that you get from trading in a VS2 Commodore and buying a new one, or from buying a new one and trading in, the net benefit to the consumer is only about $146.

Over and above that, the relevant point here is this: what plan does this government have for the car industry? The fact is that there is a buyers' strike on, both in fleet terms and in passenger market terms. People are not buying cars. And why should they? Even if it is only $146 they can save, they may as well save it. So they are postponing buying vehicles.

The Premier of South Australia, Senator Nick Minchin's colleague John Olsen, says that he has secured a deal that will see a review conducted of the introduction of the GST on the motor vehicle industry. In his answer today I think Senator Minchin clarified that there is a review, but when will the results of the review be known? What is the process? Why hasn't the government taken heed of the warnings it has been given by the fleet industry, by passenger market sales and by the retail end of the market that there is a problem? What is the plan? There is not much time to go. You will be seeing significant drop-offs in car sales. On one occasion already, the drop in car sales led to the standing down of some 3,500 workers. If that is going to continue, what is the real benefit?

Why haven't the government planned around this to introduce a staged reduction in the wholesale sales tax? Why haven't they done that? There is no plan, which means there could be a major impact on the car industry and the people working in it. I say to the minister again, and to the government: you have no plan at the moment but you ought to hurry up and get one because it is a serious problem and will have a major impact. The statements that you are making in here are not true; there is no review and you have no plan. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe trouble with going third in this debate, this attack on Senator Minchin, is that by the time my two colleagues have carved up the other side the whole debate has basically flopped over. This attack on Senator Minchin has amounted to absolutely nothing, except a waste of timeâwhich is what I believe you accused him of doing, of being distracted from his portfolio. Talk about a waste of time. The man who led this debate, Senator Schachtâas we were told by Senator Hill, and that is about when the debate fell apartâhas his preselection under attack from Senator Quirke, who purported to support him in this debate. It is the Labor Party who are totally distracted from the main game, not Senator Minchin.

speech.para: On the contrary, Senator Minchin is the most consummate performer on the front bench hereâor at least in cabinet. Before the industry and science portfolio, he was given many briefsâsuch as native title and the Constitutional Conventionâto get across. Not only did he get across these complex, difficult issuesânative title, in particularâbut he got the bill through. And there was the Constitutional Convention. So skilful is Senator Minchin at his job that he is the only man who ever got Senator Brown to vote with this government on anything. That was the only time Senator Brown used his vote to support the government, to actually swing a bit of power instead of wasting it while he babbles in the corner there, wasting a whole career.

talk.start.para: âBut that was because he thought he was going to gazump Senator Harradine, but he was too late.

âNo doubt Senator Brown's motives were not good; there is always some deviousness behind them. But the charm of Senator Minchin got him across nevertheless and the convention went ahead. Thank you, Senator Brown, though your motives be dark and deviousâas they were. Because of that, we now have the referendum on 6 Novemberâthanks to Senator Minchin. So we can see that behind most of the government's policiesâin relation to native title, in relation to the Constitutional Conventionâhe is a top performer in cabinet; we know that. We know he is a political hardhead; we do not run away from that. He is one of the most hardheaded politicians on this front bench.

speech.para: I thought across there you would actually admire that. I thought maybe Senator Quirke might get some tips from him regarding Senator Schacht. But then again Senator Schacht is an easy target. You do not have to do too much to move Senator Schacht on. I remember that when he was the minister for science he got moved on. He could not oversee that portfolio.

talk.start.para: âOrder! Senator McGauran, this has not got much to do with the steel industry or the car industry. This issue has been drawn to my attention before. So could you please, within the context of this debate, make it relevant.

âI will try. I can say, in regard to Whyalla, when I was watching the news services I saw the mayor and many other public representatives from that township actually say, `Well, it is a good thing that BHP are on-selling their steelworks.' That is completely different to shutting it down.
âWho is going to buy it?
âThat would hit a township, but they support the on-selling because it gives those steelworks a future.
âWho is going to buy it?

âA future, because the key point for those townships, as you would know, Senator Murphyâto state the obviousâis employment. Because it is going to sell the steelworks as an ongoing concern, that township welcomes BHP, which is fundamentally going through a complete restructure at the moment. It is a weak company at the moment. It is better it on-sells those steelworks so that the employment in the town can stay in the town. The steelworks can survive as an ongoing concern. So that is what I have to say about Whyalla.

speech.para: And what you brought up, Senator Murphy, about the car industry is absolute rubbish. You were misquoting the figures. Senator Minchin was making the point that, if the sales of cars continue this year, we will have a record year of car sales. At the very least, it will be the third best year. Last year was a record and the year before was a record. When we look at this year's sales graphâand we admit this year has not finishedâwhat we can say is that, in June 2000, the car industry will receive its greatest advantage through the reduction in sales tax by some 22 per cent, and that will continue on ad infinitum. Not many industries can claim that their industry will get a 22 per cent tax reduction which will lead to cheaper cars.

talk.start.para: âOrder! The time for the debate has elapsed.
âPetitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes any attempts by the Australian government to mine uranium at the Jabiluka and Koongara sites in the World Heritage Listed Area of the Kakadu National Park or any other proposed or current operating site.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate oppose any intentions by the Australian government to support the nuclear industry via any mining, enrichment and sale of uranium.

talk.start.para: Senator Allison(from 314 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled:
The Petition of the Undersigned shows that we believe that the current Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Scheme provides benefits to retired members which are overly generous and unfair.
Your petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
Act swiftly to bring the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Scheme in line with community standards by:
(1) Reducing the taxpayer subsidy which currently stands at an average of $6 contributed by taxpayers for every $1 contributed by Senators and members;
(2) Instructing the Remuneration Tribunal to substantially reduce benefits;
(3) Removing the early payment of benefits, so that they are payable at the age of 55 in line with the rest of the community;
(4) Supporting the Australian Democrats' Private Members' Bill to overhaul the politicians' superannuation scheme to achieve these aims.

talk.start.para: Senator Allison(from 467 citizens)

petitioninfo.title: World Heritage Area: Great Barrier Reef

petition.para: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows strong disappointment in the Australian Government's inadequate protection of the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage Area from the destructive practices of prawn trawling. Prawn trawling destroys up to 10 tonnes of other reef life for every one tonne of prawns while clearfelling the sea floor. There are 11 million square kilometres of Australia's ocean territory of which the reef represents just 350,000 square kilometres.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate support the phasing out of all prawn trawling in the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage Area by the year 2005.

talk.start.para: Senator Bartlett(from 12 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate the deleterious effects of the Multilateral Agreement on Investment.
Your petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. Make available the draft text of the Agreement;
2. Make a public statement about its intentions with regard to the signing of the MAI, detailing the beneficiaries of the Agreement, and accountability measures for all corporations;
3. Not sign the MAI unless substantive amendment is made, including the observance of interna tional agreements including environment, labour, health and safety and human rights standards;
4. Extend the deadline for signing the MAI to enable full and proper public consultations to be held.

talk.start.para: Senator Bourne(from four citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition undersigned shows:
(1) There is a likelihood that amendments to the federal anti-discrimination legislation are to be introduced to the federal senate in 1999.

(2) These amendments will take the exclusion clause away for all religious organisations from not employing or not accepting practicing homosexuals within their organisations due to their religious beliefs.
(3) That these amendments could be of great concern to different groups within the community.
The petitioners ask and seek the federal government that it:
(1) Reject any amendments to take away the right of religious organisations to reject the employment of homosexuals when it infringes upon the organisations religious beliefs.
(2) Reject amendments, which are contrary to S116 of the constitution, which states that the government can not make any law that interferes with the practice of religion.

(3) Recognise that in part 1 section B:25 page 24 of the 1999 draft resolution on the Commission on Human Rights Report on the Fifty-fifth Session (22 March-30 April 1999) from the United Nations, a right of belief of faith is a fundamental right for all religious bodies. Australia needs to keep hold to this article which we the Country of Australia has already signed.

talk.start.para: Senator Tierney(from 208 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable President of the Senate and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.

This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that the people of East Timor have overwhelmingly voted to become an independent and sovereign nation and the Indonesian Government has failed to fulfil its responsibility to maintain security in East Timor during the period of transition to independence.
We therefore petition the House to require the Government and all responsible Ministers to:
Withdraw Australia's original de jure recognition of Indonesia's annexation of East Timor;
Suspend Australia's remaining military ties with Indonesia;
Support calls for international institutions to suspend all financial assistance to Indonesia;
Advise the Indonesian Government to direct forthwith the Indonesian Army to disarm the pro-Jakarta militia in East Timor; and
Advise the Indonesian Government to authorise forthwith the UN to dispatch a peacekeeping force to East Timor
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

talk.start.para: Senator West(from six citizens)
âI give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the provisions of paragraphs (5) to (7) of standing order 111 not apply to the Fisheries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1999, allowing it to be considered during this period of sittings.
I also table a statement of reasons justifying the need for this bill to be considered during this sittings and seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The statement read as followsâ

para.inline: STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1999 SPRING SITTINGS

speech.para: The proposed amendments implement key reforms to Commonwealth fisheries management legislation necessary to combat the increasing problem of illegal and unregulated foreign fishing. They include provision of a more effective forfeiture scheme against foreign fishers and a doubling of penalties. The amendments will also enable Australia to ratify an important international fisheries management agreementâthe Agreement for the Implementation of the Provisions of the United Nations Law of the Sea of 10 December 1982 Relating to the Conservation and Management of Straddling Fish Stocks and Highly Migratory Fish Stocks (the UN Fish Stocks Agreement)âwhich will assist in combating illegal fishing. Implementing the Agreement is also vital to ensure the sustainability of valuable fish stocks, such as Southern Bluefin Tuna, Orange Roughy and Patagonian Toothfish, on which our domestic industry relies, both within and outside the Australian Fishing Zone (AFZ).

Illegal foreign fishing impacts on the sustainability of resources and adversely affects the Australian domestic fishing industry The fish stocks affected are high value species on which our domestic industry relies. Illegal fishing undermines the strict environmental controls imposed on Australian vessels fishing on the high seas, and the sustainable management measures taken within the AFZ.

Australia signed the UN Fish Stocks Agreement in December 1995 and there is increasing pressure from industry and conservation organisations to ratify and implement it. Twenty-three countries have already ratified the Agreement to date and it will come into force once the number reaches 30. It is understood that New Zealand will be in a position to ratify in November 1999, and a number of other countries are well advanced in the process towards ratification. Australia is recognised as a world leader in fisheries management and played an active role in negotiating the Agreement. Being an original party to the Agreement (in the first 30 countries) will ensure that our reputation as a leader in sustainable fisheries management is maintained.

The Government committed to ratifying the UN Fish Stocks Agreement in Australia's Oceans Policy, launched in December 1998. At the recent meeting of the Ministerial Council on Forestry, Fisheries and Aquaculture, Ministers endorsed proceeding towards ratification of the Agreement. The amendments are consistent with current Australian fisheries management and environment policy. Industry and the Commonwealth will benefit from expeditious implementation.

Based on consultation to date, there is general agreement amongst Government, industry and conservation groups that the benefits to be gained from implementing the Agreement far outweigh the costs. Extensive consultation with these groups will continue to occur on the practical implementation of the Agreement. This will enable increased understanding of the implications and costs and assist in minimising administrative complexity.

Without ratification Australia would not be in a position to authorise fishing on the high seas which would have adverse financial and operational impacts on industry. There would be negative implications for successful enforcement of Australian action against illegal foreign fishers.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry)

talk.start.para: âBefore giving a notice of motion, I seek leave to make a brief statement in relation to the notice.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI thank the Senate. My statement relates to the return to order from Minister Newman. The minister was required to table a discussion paper at 3 p.m. today. Whilst she tabled the terms of reference of her reference group, she indicated that she was not willing to table the discussion paper. She indicated that it would be tabled in the Senate when she provides it to the reference group and that she was still preparing the discussion paper for the reference group.

speech.para: I would like to indicate prior to giving notice of this motion that, given I moved for the return to order, it was very clear that a discussion paper was prepared prior to the minister's National Press Club speech, and that was what the return to order related to. We are usually provided with a number of reasons by ministers when they choose not to comply with returns to orderâwhich does not happen that oftenâwhich relate to commercial-in-confidence, legal advice and matters such as those. None of those reasons were put forward by the minister. The only possible reason could be one of political management, which is maybe what the government is concerned about. But, from the point of view of the parliament, we are here to scrutinise the actions of the executive and we have made an order of the Senate requiring this paper to be tabled. We cannot accept a duck-and-weave approach to debate on an important issue such as this. That is the reason I am proceeding with giving notice of this motion. Therefore, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:
(1) That the Senate:

(a) censures the Minister for Family and Community Services (Senator Newman) for her contempt of the Senate in failing to comply with an order made on 30 September 1999, that a document, namely the welfare reform discussion paper originally prepared for her Press Club speech on 29 September 1999, and now being provided to the Minister's newly-established reference group on welfare reform, be tabled by 3 pm on 12 October 1999; and
(b) resolves that:
(i) the Minister purge the contempt in which she has held the Senate by tabling the document on or before 3 pm on 18 October 1999,
(ii) if the document is not tabled by this time, the question on any motion moved by the Minister for:
(a) the introduction of any bill,
(b) the consideration of any stage of any bill, or
(c) in committee of the whole, any amendment or any request for amendment to any bill,
not be put until the Minister has undertaken to lay the document on the table, and
(iii) the Minister not be heard on any other matter relating to her activities as a minister.
(2) That this resolution remain in force until either the document is tabled or until the last sitting day of 1999, whichever is earlier.

(3) That, as the first item of business on the Monday of each sitting week, the Minister be required to make a statement to the Senate outlining whether she is intending to comply with the order and, if not, outlining her reasons, and a motion may be moved without notice to take note of the Minister's statement.
Senator Calvert, at the request of Senator Tierney, to move, on the next day of sitting:
That the Senateâ
(a) notes:
(i) that on 30 September 1999, BHP shut down its steel smelting operations in Newcastle and case-managed the affected workers through its Jobs Pathways Program, and

(ii) that, as the global `knowledge' economy moves from the smokestack age to the information technology age, the Hunter region is one of the regions in Australia to spearhead that change and is set for a brighter future;

(b) commends the Howard Government for its pro-active role in acting as a `change leader' through the Prime Minister's Hunter Structural Assistance Package, which has generated some 804 direct jobs, with some further 4 000 indirect jobs to follow; and

talk.start.para: âI ask that general business notice of motion No. 318 standing in my name for today, relating to a call to the Australian government to withdraw de jure recognition of Indonesian control and rule in East Timor, be taken as a formal motion.

âby leaveâConsistent with the view of the opposition in relation to general business motions which are contentious, the opposition does not agree to formality. In this case, we support the motion to be moved by Senator Brown. We understand the government opposes the motion. We would not want the matter to go through without debate but indicate that, if it is so moved, we will be supporting a motion to suspend to allow the motion to be dealt with immediately.
âI thank Senator O'Brien for that explanation. Pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in my name, I move:

speech.para: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Brown moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion no. 318.

This matter is both urgent and important. There arose in 1978, after the invasion of East Timor by the Indonesian military in 1975, the situation where Australia became the one country that gave effective recognition of Indonesian's control of East Timor.

talk.start.para: âCan I make an attempt at a constructive and helpful point of order to indicate that, as the numbers are there for the suspension, perhaps we could save a bit of time by having these motions carried and move to the substantive debate.
âI would be prepared to do that.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Brown) agreed to:
That general business notice of motion no. 318 may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business today till determined.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senateâ
(a) notes the overwhelming vote for independence of the East Timorese people and Indonesian President Habibie's endorsement of this outcome; and
(b) calls on the Australian Government to withdraw its de jure recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor.

As I was saying a moment ago, in 1975 the Indonesian military invaded and took control of East Timor against the wishes of the people. In 1976, President Suharto signed a bill declaring that East Timor was Indonesia's 27th province. But the United Nations did not recognise that and said that Portugal remained the administering power. Notwithstanding that, on 20 January 1978, Australiaâthe Fraser governmentâgranted de facto recognition to Indonesia's control of East Timor. At the time, Mr Andrew Peacock was the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In February 1979, Australia extended de jure recognition to Indonesia's rule in East Timor and became the one country in the world to do so.

As we know, there has been a terrible process for the East Timorese people ever since, which has left many Australians aghast at those events and also at the very forward role Australia took in recognising the Indonesian authority over East Timor which gave at least a veneer of legitimacy to the domination of East Timor by massive military repression.

Things have now greatly changed. In the wake of the overwhelming vote by the East Timorese people, the world sees East Timor as moving rapidly towards full independence as a small nation which will join the community of nations in full independence. Before the referendum, the Indonesian authorities indicated that they would be very accommodating to moving towards recognising independence if that was the wish of the people. In the wake of the referendum, President Habibie has endorsed the outcome.

The process is now for a meeting of the Indonesian parliament to give its full endorsement as far as Indonesia is concerned, but the world recognises East Timor's right to independence. However, there remains Australian recognition of control and rule over East Timor by Indonesia. This is despite the fact that Indonesia has withdrawn every single member of its armed forces, in an official capacity at least, from East Timor, burning and pillaging as it went. Nevertheless, there is no remaining rule or control by Indonesia over East Timorânone whatever. It then becomes an absurdity for Australia to maintain its recognition of that control and rule.

I do not know why the Howard government has not in the wake of the referendum reversed the decisions of 1978 and 1979, but at some stage or other those decisions ought to be reversed. I move a lot amongst people who have been in the protests, who have supported the independence of East Timor and who have wanted Australia to send peacekeepers. There has been a very strong call amongst those people for months now for Australia to reverse its recognition of Indonesian control over East Timor now that the people of East Timor have spoken overwhelmingly for their independence. We are in an absurd situation. It is ridiculous that the Australian government effectively recognises East Timor as being under the control of Indonesia when patently that is not so and everybody can see that is not so.

I am one of the many Australians who believe we never should have given any form of recognition to the Indonesian military's control of this poor benighted neighbour of ours of East Timor. But now the time has come for that to be reversed by those people who thought it was a good thing, and that includes the current government of Australia, which came to office endorsing that proclamation of recognition of Indonesian control. Events have moved rapidly, they have moved far, there has been a turnaround, and the world recognises no longer that Indonesia has control over East Timor. The world recognises that East Timor, if it is de facto anything, is in de facto control of its own destiny. What we will see in the wake of the peacekeeping mission to East Timor is the development of administration, security and democratic government.

We are at this moment hosting Xanana Gusmao on our soil. Australians have warmed to this leader of the East Timorese and have warmed to his giving, his magnanimity and his humanity. Yet, at an official level, we have this absurd notion by Australia that the East Timorese are not in control of their affairs, and that Indonesia, which has totally withdrawn from the country, is still in control. It is sensible diplomacy that we reverse that. This is a call, if it succeeds here today, to the government to recognise the need to remove yet another barrier to not only our accommodation of and assistance to East Timor but a very necessary rapprochement with Indonesia itself. This is an historic remnant, an impediment, an anachronism. This recognition ought to be removed. I commend this motion to the Senate.

talk.start.para: âThe Democrats naturally support this motion. This is something that we have been calling for since 1981. The earliest reference I could find on the parliamentary database was in 1981 when Senator Colin Mason was asking questions of the then Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. Ever since then we have been calling for it. We have had no luck.

speech.para: I am sure senators are aware that de jure actually means `by right'. I do not think anybody in this chamber, or probably in Australia, would agree that Indonesia has any right to East Timor. They certainly invaded, took it over and were there for a long timeâ24 yearsâbut I do not think anybody thinks that they have a right to remain there. Senators will also know, if they have read the 5 May agreement between Portugal, Indonesia and the United Nations, that it says that if the vote is in favour of independence, or not in favour of autonomy as it was put in the agreementâI hope I am getting this right because I do not have it in front of meâthe effect is that the Indonesia government would do everything they needed to do in order to allow the people of East Timor their independence. That vote did go in favour of independence and against autonomy. So even the 5 May agreement of this year between Jaime Gama on behalf of Portugal, Ali Alatas on behalf of Indonesia and Kofi Annan on behalf of the United Nations acknowledged that the vote was the final substantive issue in this whole saga and that that vote would determine the actions of the Indonesian parliament.

I am sure they will stand by that; I am sure that that is the case. I am sure that the Indonesian parliament will when it meets, which should be in a couple of weeks, determine that they no longer believe East Timor to be the 27th province of Indonesia. I must say I never believed it to be the 27th province, and it has now become very clear that at least 80 per cent of the East Timorese people never believed it to be the 27th province either. I see no problem at all in anyone voting for this motion. I cannot even see a problem in the government voting for it. I certainly have no problem, and I do not believe the opposition has a problem, with this motion. I think that it is a nice finishing off of Australia's attitude to East Timor. After the last 24 years, this would be a very nice finishing off, that is, removing the fact that the Australian government believes Indonesia ever had or, in particular, has now a right to the territory that is encased in East Timor.

talk.start.para: âThe government will be opposing this motion. We are opposing it because, in essence, we regard the proposal for this action at the moment to be somewhat gratuitous, particularly in the wake of the 5 May tripartite agreement. Regardless of the debate about recognition of sovereignty over East Timor in the past, the achievement of the United Nationsâwith a significant contribution by the government of Australia under the leadership of our Prime Minister, John Howardâis, and the reality is, that there is a process in place that most commentators, and particularly the Australian government, expect will lead to independence for East Timor.

speech.para: As anticipated under the tripartite agreement of 5 May, the MPRâthe People's Consultative Assemblyâare to consider a motion which would effectively lead to a decree of separation. We expect that that will occur by no later than the end of this month. Once that takes place, there will be an end to the de jure recognition and Indonesian sovereignty. There would be a passing over to Portugal, which would be designated as the de jure administering power, but in practice the agreement provides that a UN transitional authority will be responsible, de facto, for the administration of the territory. As we have all seen in recent days, the UN are moving quickly to put that in place.

After many years of effort by many people around the world and most particularly in Australia, this process is leading to independence for the East Timorese. That is the reality. It is something we should welcome. It is something we should applaud. It is something we should continue to work for on a daily basis, as people in this parliament and people in this government are doing. To seek to change the de jure recognition of Indonesian sovereignty at this stage is therefore regarded by the government as entirely gratuitous. It would not move us positively through the process that is envisaged by the tripartite agreement.

That is not to say that if something goes wrong with the considerations within the MPRâand we certainly hope it does not, nor do we expect it toâother options do not exist. But we certainly fully expect that the process that has been set in train will see independence in East Timor, with the vote firstly of the People's Consultative Assembly, then the move to a decree of separation, the move through the UN transitional authority stage and the move to democracy and independence for the East Timorese people. This motion will not aid that process and will not aid the independence of the East Timorese people.

talk.start.para: âThe Australian Labor Party support the motion of Senator Brown. It is probably worth recalling what the motion says. It is a simple one; it contains two parts, which read:

speech.para: (a) notes the overwhelming vote for independence of the East Timorese people and Indonesian President Habibie's endorsement of this outcome; and
(b) calls on the Australian Government to withdraw its de jure recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor.

That is a motion we support. While recognising that part (b) of that motion is the contentious element, I will spend a few minutes recapping for the historical record the signifi cance of what part (a) says before I turn to the argument in support of part (b).

On 30 August this year, under the auspices of the United Nations, a ballot was conducted in East Timor with the question before the population being: do you want to be an autonomous province of Indonesia or do you vote for independence? There was a massive enrolment leading up to that ballot. Of a population of something like 850,000 peopleâmen, women and childrenâsome 450,000 people were enrolled. It was regarded by the UN observers as a most impressive readiness and willingness to enrol and as demonstrating a desire to commit to the process set down by the United Nations.

On the day of the ballot, 30 August, 99 per cent of those enrolled and able to vote turned out to vote. The reports that day were of long queues early in the morning waiting for polling stations to open. The reports were of peopleâmany of them captured in dramatic footage on televisionâwho had come out of hiding, down from the mountains and out of the jungle to express openly a choice on their own future, at some personal risk to themselves, as they believed, and upon voting they melted back to whence they had come. With that 99 per cent turnout and that early vote, when the vote tally was made 78 per cent of those voting voted for independence. A 78 per cent margin is a massive margin on an issueâthe community of East Timor's view about their future and whether they should remain an autonomous province or notâthat was thought by some, obviously and clearly wrongly, to have been a contentious issue.

The act of that vote and that overwhelming endorsement leads one to a logical consideration of de jure recognition. The government has said that it would be `gratuitous' for Australiaâin recognition of the process in place to move to independenceâto now remove de jure recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor. There is a process in place. The government is right about that, and I want to remark on that in a moment. But we ourselves are a sovereign nation and we ourselves are masters of our own destiny and responsible and accountable for what we do. Nothing that we do here will disrupt the process and nothing that we do here will interfere with the movement to independence. But what we do here will say a lot about how we feel about that voteâthat cry for independenceâand where Australia stands in supporting it.

The Labor Party support this motion because it will enable us to now remove recognition from Indonesia as an act of our own and provide recognition to the independence vote that has been given. It is important that Australia say something about where we stand on this matter because of the devastation, murder and destruction wreaked in East Timor since that vote for independence; the need to put in a peacekeeping force under the United Nations' commandâprovided mostly from Australia but, importantly, also from many other sources; the levelling of the community; the discovery now of mass graves; the clear involvement of the militia; the consistent reports of links between the Indonesian army and that militia; and the reports that are now emanating out of West Timor of military renegades training insurgent guerrillas in the form of that militia to harass and fight in East Timor. This motion of Senator Brown's enables us to say something, and that is why we will support it.

The key argument of the government is that the process would be disrupted and we would be gratuitous if we did that. I now want to turn to article 6 of the tripartite agreement of 5 May, the agreement which set down Indonesia's obligations in the event of a vote for independence, to put on the record in this chamber what the binding responsibility is on Indonesia under the UN brokered tripartite agreement. Article 6 reads:

. . . the Government of Indonesia shall take the constitutional steps necessary to terminate its links with East Timor thus restoring under Indonesian law the status East Timor held prior to 17 July 1976, and the Governments of Indonesia and Portugal and the Secretary-General shall agree on arrangements for a peaceful and orderly transfer of authority in East Timor to the United Nations. The Secretary-General shall, subject to the appropriate legislative mandate, initiate the procedure enabling East Timor to begin a process of transition towards independence.
That is the tripartite agreement that gave force to the ballot for independence in East Timor, signed by the United Nations, Indonesia and Portugal. The last sentence of it bears repetition:
The Secretary-General shall, subject to the appropriate legislative mandate, initiate the procedure enabling East Timor to begin a process of transition towards independence.

The `appropriate legislative mandate' is, of course, a meeting of the Indonesian parliamentâwhich may occur in the next eight or 10 daysâat which it is expected there will be a vote to recognise the outcome of the ballot conducted in East Timor.

Given that the government's position is that it would be gratuitous to endorse this motion and that there is a process that this motion may interfere with, it is important to record in this debate that on 7 October the various factions in the Indonesian parliament, the MPRâits proper name in English is the Indonesian People's Consultative Assembly, known in Bahasa Malay as the MPRâagreed to implement the outcome of East Timor's independence ballot. Because they have done that, it is important to note that, on the day of the meeting of the MPR, it appears absolutely certain that Indonesia will recognise the ballot for independence and the process in train under article 6 of the tripartite agreement of 5 May will begin.

I want to pause on that point for a moment, because it is an important point. This motion acknowledges that President Habibie has recognised and endorsed the outcome of the independence ballot. But, as any observer of Indonesian politics knows, President Habibie at the moment is, in the view of several commentators, struggling to gain the endorsement of his own party, the Golkar Party, and even if he did he may not succeed in winning the presidential election in the MPR when it convenes to select the President. Indeed, most observers predict strongly that the outcome will be that Megawati Sukarnoputri will become the President of Indonesia on that day. That seems to be now a brokered deal.

The fact that President Habibie has endorsed the outcome of the independence ballot is significant, but even more compelling is that all factionsâincluding the one that is likely to provide the President and including the armed forces, who have a legislative presence in the Indonesian parliament, providing about one-third of members, I thinkâhave endorsed the move to independence in East Timor. So the process that is in place will not be disrupted, and if it were to be disrupted there would be genuine reason to pause and say, `Let's not disrupt this process; let's get the independence done and put aside our need to express a view.' But there is no such cloud on the horizon, and it seems to me entirely appropriate that we can take a view here of expressing our attitude to this issue without in any way affecting the outcome, given the agreement by the various factions in Indonesia.

I want to bring my remarks to a conclusion but, before I do that, what has outraged, shocked and horrified most people in the global community and nearly everyone in Australia is that, after the declaration of the poll in Indonesia, after the announcement that 78 per cent of those voting had voted for independence, a horrific campaign was conducted, seemingly in a well-organised, pre-planned way, that drove people out of the country of East Timor. It is also apparent that that was led, of course, by the militia. It is also apparent that it was done either under the benign gaze of the Indonesian military or in some cases with the support of elements of the Indonesian military, and it appears to be the case now that there are some elements of the Indonesian military conspiring to train militia to run insurgency operations in East Timor.

I would have thought that there was an obligation of good housekeeping on Indonesia after the ballot to ensure that the peaceful transition that the world hoped would be achieved was in fact delivered. What has happened is far from a peaceful transition, necessitating again the intervention of a United Nations peacekeeping force. I might say in parenthesis that this is something the Australian Labor Party had called for early on, because when the 5 May agreement was reached and it was decided to have an early ballot, some voices were raised about running too quickly into such a ballot without there being a provision for the security of the people in East Timor, lest that lead to civil disturbance. Xanana Gusmao, the putative President of the new republic of East Timor, was one of those voices that raised concern that people may be at risk should there not be security cover. The Australian Labor Party was one of the organisations that raised concerns about this at that time too and talked about the need for a peacekeeping force then as well.

Now I turn to part (b) of this motion, which calls on the Australian government to withdraw its de jure recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor. We are in a transition phase. The transition is on track in terms of the technical steps necessary to deliver it, and there is clearly a lot that has to be done to re-establish East Timor as a viable entity. This motion asks that Australia now withdraw its recognition that Indonesia has sovereignty. Given all of the developments that have occurred, it is appropriate that we now do so. It will not interfere with the transition. It will not mean that independence is not granted. I would contend that it is not a `gratuitous' act but a responsible one and a necessary one to state where we stand and how we recognise the determination by the East Timorese. Because of that, I support the motion.

talk.start.para: âI just want to make a quick explanation under standing order 191. I will not delay the Senate. It is not something I would do very often. Senator Cook implied, I do not think maliciously at all, that I had said it was gratuitous to do this because it may interfere with or upset the process that will be put in train as part of the tripartite agreement. I did not say that. I am happy to be corrected if the Hansard shows otherwise. I am saying it is gratuitous because there is in place a process, and it is only gratuitous because it is a process which is leading to the end which I think we all agree on anyway, and to take the action that is proposed by Senator Brown today would be gratuitous in those terms. Further, because on 5 May or thereabouts Australia had expressed a very explicit commitment to that agreement and that agreement encompasses the continuation of de jure recognition of Indonesian sovereignty until their parliament has taken action, it would be changing Australia's commitments midstream, which is undesirable. I hope Senator Cook did not infer that it would undermine the process. I am saying it is gratuitous because this process exists already and therefore it would not achieve anything.

âI will make a quick remark on that, with the permission of the chamber, if I may. I did not mean any maliciousness in my remarks, and I acknowledge, Senator Campbell, that you recognise that too. But I am aware that on 10 September the Prime Minister made similar remarks on the ABC Radio National program and, as a consequence, my remarks were couched that way. The only point I was seeking to make is that, whatever that process might be, that is a process by the United Nations, Indonesia and Portugal. Australia should speak in its own voiceâthis nation should speak for itselfâand this motion enables it to do so by withdrawing de jure recognition.

âI thank all sides of the chamber for their contributions to the debate on this very important motion. The government has effectively said that the edict from 1978 whereby Australia gave recognition to Indonesian control of East Timor stands and that it would be gratuitous to remove it. It was gratuitous to make that stand in 1978. If, as the government says, this is gratuitous, why not follow the same course in reversing what is now a harmful anachronism?

speech.para: The reasons that the government has given do not really stack up. I believe that the passage of this motion into effect, with the government adopting a call from the Senate to reverse the 1978 recognition of Indonesian control of East Timor, would have a positive influence on the deliberations of the Indonesian parliament in the next week or so. It would be the end of another impediment from times past to clearing the air and would help ensure that the Indonesian parliament does make the right vote and recognise the vote of the East Timorese people.

Secondly, I believe that it would give a timely encouragement to the East Timorese people that their interests are considered paramount as far as their relationship with their country is concerned. There is an increasing absurdity in the situation where Australia clings to an outdated, outmoded and clearly ridiculous position of recognising Indonesian control over East Timor when that control has been relinquished and the Indonesian military has been withdrawn.

Finally, I believe it is very important to the international peacekeeping force in East Timor, including the very large Australian contingent there, that this de facto recognition of Indonesian authority is removed. It does inherently give some sanctionâtotally unintended, unwanted and against the wish of everybody in this parliamentâto people acting with some authority from Jakarta in crossing the West Timorese border, for example. Australia is then in the absurd position of saying, `Well, Indonesia does retain control over East Timor.' It is an absurdity and it ought to be ended.

It is not a gratuitous act to remove the recognition of Indonesian control; it is supreme logical commonsense. I hope the government will think again. It is past time that the government should have made this move and I hope that, if this vote succeedsâas I believe it willâthe government will give it very serious consideration and will move to reverse the 1978 edict to help pave the way for the Indonesian parliament to make the right decision in the coming fortnight.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

debateinfo.title: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

debate.para: A message received from the House of Representatives agreeing to the amendments made by the Senate to the following bill:

cognateinfo.title: A NEW TAX SYSTEM (TAX ADMINISTRATION) BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Bills received from the House of Representatives.

talk.start.para: âI indicate to the Senate that these bills which have just been announced are being introduced together. After debate on the motion for the second reading has been adjourned, I will be moving a motion to have the bills listed separately on the Notice Paper . I move:

speech.para: That these bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

talk.start.para: âI table revised explanatory memoranda relating to the Indigenous Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999 and the Electronic Transactions Bill 1999. I move:

speech.para: That these bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speeches read as followsâ
INDIGENOUS EDUCATION (SUPPLEMENTARY ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1999

The bill amends the Indigenous Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989 to give effect to initiatives announced in the 1999-2000 Budget. The bill will provide for the continuation of the Indigenous Education Strategic Initiatives Program (IESIP) for the 2000 calendar year including the application of cost supplementation to these new funds.

Further, the bill provides for the continuation of the mixed mode course delivery away-from-base element of the ABSTUDY scheme which will now operate more effectively under IESIP. This bill specifically contains funding arrangements for education providers delivering ABSTUDY approved courses during 2000.

The bill contains a consequential amendment to the Student Assistance Act 1973 transferring the appropriation of the away-from-base element of the ABSTUDY scheme to the Indigenous Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989.

The passage of this bill will enable the Commonwealth to play its part, in concert with the States and Territories, in pursuing the goal of educational equity for our Indigenous students by 2004. This goal is vital if Indigenous people and communities are to enjoy the many opportunities available in Australia.

This bill relates specifically to the year 2000. IESIP funding (including the away-from-base element of ABSTUDY) will continue to the year 2004. Further legislation for Indigenous Education (Supplementary Assistance) will be introduced during 2000 with the aim of more closely aligning this with States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) legislation which operates on a quadrennial basis. This is due to commence a new quadrennium in 2001. It is hoped that this will result in consistency between the acts in areas such as educational and financial accountability and other outcomes requirements.

This bill proposes changes in the administration of the ABSTUDY scheme. This follows the Review of ABSTUDY which was undertaken in 1998 in the context of the introduction of the Youth Allowance. The Review has informed the government's recent decisions on ABSTUDY. On 15 December 1998, the government announced that ABSTUDY would be retained as a separate scheme and that changes to it would be implemented on 1 January 2000. These changes improve opportunities for disadvantaged Indigenous people.

Specifically, the mixed-mode course delivery away-from-base element is to be transferred from ABSTUDY to IESIP in the form of block grants to institutions. As IESIP currently provides supplementary assistance to education providers under outcomes focussed agreements, away-from-base assistance will build onto these existing agreements and monitoring arrangements.

ABSTUDY away-from-base assistance is designed to help meet travel costs, meals and accommodation for students participating in compulsory course activities such as placements, residential schools and field trips. The `mixed mode' courses, that are part of the away-from-base activities, are delivered through a combination of distance education and face-to-face teaching. It is generally acknowledged that this method of course delivery is more culturally appropriate than on-campus delivery for many Indigenous students from remote areas as it enables the student to remain in the community for much of the time but still receive the support of face-to-face teaching. This is an important aspect that allows Indigenous Australians with community obligations to participate and benefit from higher education.

The block grant amount paid to each provider in the Year 2000 will be determined by a formula which takes into account the number of eligible Indigenous students enrolled in 2000 and an Education Provider Unit Cost, based on 1998 allocations, which varies from provider to provider.

The ABSTUDY changes will not decrease the government's financial commitment to Indigenous education. While there may be some reduction in the forward estimates for ABSTUDY, the funds will be redirected to other areas of Indigenous education.
This funding affirms the Commonwealth's commitment to Indigenous education in Australia.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
ELECTRONIC TRANSACTIONS BILL 1999

In December 1997 the Prime Minister made a commitment in his Investing for Growth statement to develop a light-handed regulatory framework for the online environment which supports and encourages business and consumer confidence in the use of electronic commerce. The Electronic Transactions Bill 1999 delivers on this commitment, balancing the need for greater certainty against flexibility for business and the community as the prime movers in the information economy. It removes existing impediments to electronic commerce in Commonwealth law and facilitates the development of new opportunities for business and the community in the information economy.

The Government recognises that it is essential that we have an internationally consistent approach to electronic commerce legislation. The Electronic Transactions Bill is based on the Model Law on Electronic Commerce prepared by the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law, as modified by the recommendations of the Electronic Commerce Expert Group which reported to me in March 1998. The Model Law is recognised as the leading international template for electronic commerce legislation. Australia has encouraged other jurisdictions to adopt the Model Law through our involvement in a number of international forums including APEC and the OECD.

The Government has successfully sought the cooperation of the States and Territories to develop a national legal framework for electronic commerce. The bill is the blueprint for national uniform legislation that will remove legal impediments and facilitate the growth of electronic commerce in Australia. At the April meeting of the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General all Attorneys-General agreed to implement uniform legislation in their jurisdictions.

The bill is the result of extensive public consultation. This implements the policy statement that the Prime Minister made in his `Investing for Growth' statement in December 1997 that business should lead the development of the information economy in Australia. We sought the views of the public on the report of the Electronic Commerce Expert Group before finalising the Government's response to the Expert Group's recommendations. The responses we received indicated clear support for the work of the Expert Group.

The Government then developed draft legislation to put the recommendations of the Expert Group into effect. The exposure draft of the bill was released for public comment in January 1999. Seventy-three submissions were received on the bill, thirty-five of which were from the private sector. All submissions supported the intention, structure and content of the bill. A range of policy and drafting issues were also raised which have been considered in finalising the bill.

Australia was one of the first countries to publicly state its intention to implement the UNCITRAL Model Law. There is very little legislation internationally that is as comprehensive as this bill. While the Model Law is widely recognised internationally as an important document it is only now being considered for adoption in many countries. This Government was early in recognising the need for legislation like this bill and has moved swiftly to implement it.

The bill is based on two fundamental principles. The first is `media neutrality', which means that paper-based commerce and electronic commerce should be treated equally by the law. Secondly, the principle of `technology neutrality' ensures that the law does not discriminate between different forms of technology.

As current Australian law neither recognises nor denies the validity of electronic communications, the bill establishes the basic rule that a transaction is not invalid because it took place by means of an electronic communication.

Following this general rule, the bill sets out specific provisions which state that a requirement or permission under a law of the Commonwealth for a person to provide information in writing, to sign or produce a document, or to retain information or a document can be satisfied in electronic form, subject to certain minimum criteria being satisfied.

While some jurisdictions overseas have enacted technology specific legislation dealing with digital signatures, we have taken a flexible technology neutral approach that allows electronic signatures to meet existing requirements for hand written signatures, subject to certain minimum criteria.

The bill also contains clauses that establish rules, which will apply in the absence of any contrary agreement, dealing with the time and place of dispatch and receipt of electronic communications and the attribution of electronic communications.

The bill has a two-step implementation process. Prior to 1 July 2001, the bill will only apply to laws of the Commonwealth specified in regulations. After that date, the bill will apply to all laws of the Commonwealth unless they have been specifically excluded from the application of the bill.
A NEW TAX SYSTEM (TAX ADMINISTRATION) BILL 1999
A New Tax System (Tax Administration) Bill 1999 will implement remaining tax administration measures of the new taxation system.

Firstly, when the new tax system commences on 1 July next, taxpayers with simple affairs will have more certainty that their annual tax return is finalised, because this bill reduces the time in which a review can be made from four years to two years.
Secondly, taxpayers with simple affairs will also be able to get oral advice from the Commissioner of Taxation that is binding on the commissioner.

Thirdly, our reforms do away with reporting systems, such as the reportable payments system, that are a significant compliance burden on business. The modern integrated design of the new tax system reduces the need for add-on reporting systems.

However, the government recognises that there is a need to be able to respond quickly if systematic tax evasion is detected in an industry. One of the measures in this bill provides for an Australian business number, ABN, based reporting system. The system would only be activated after consultation with the affected industry, would only apply to certain transactions within the industry and would only operate for a specified period.

Fourthly, the government's tax reform package also included a more transparent endorsement process for tax exempt and gift deductible bodies. In coming months, the Australian Business Registrar will commence the Australian business number registration process. Charities and deductible gift recipients will be required to obtain an Australian business number and be endorsed by the Commissioner of Taxation in order to obtain either income tax exemption or deductible gift recipient status.
Finally, the bill will also make some minor amendments to support the introduction of pay as you go, PAYG, and the single activity statement for business.
Full details of the measures in the bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum.
I commend the bill.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of these bills be adjourned till the first day of the summer sittings in 1999, in accordance with standing order 111.
Ordered that these bills be listed on the Notice Paper as separate orders of the day.

debate.para: A message from His Excellency the Governor-General was reported, informing the Senate that he had assented to the following law:

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 11 October, on motion by Senator Heffernan:
That these bills be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Conroy had moved by way of amendment:

At the end of the motion, add "but the Senate expresses its concern about the failure of the Government to provide for a review of the future of the automotive industry before tariffs are reduced in 2005".

talk.start.para: âI think I have completed all that I wish to say in relation to the second reading debate on this bill and I thank members who have contributed to the debate for their contributions.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: The bill.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: Page 103 (after line 25), after clause 116, insert:

(1) Before 1 July 2003 the Minister must cause to be established an independent inquiry into the future of Australia's automotive industry. The inquiry must address, in particular, the most appropriate rates of customs duty to apply from 1 January 2005 on passenger motor vehicles and the categories of related componentry and products specified in this Act.

(2) After the Minister receives the report of the inquiry established under subsection (1) the Minister may issue a written certificate stating that the Minister has received the report and is satisfied rates of customs should be amended from the inquiry certificate day as provided in this Act.
(3) The Minister must arrange for a copy of a certificate issued under subsection (2) to be published in the Gazette.
(4) Subject to subsection (5), the day on which a certificate issued under subsection (2) is published in the Gazette is the inquiry certificate day .
(5) If the copy of the certificate issued under subsection (2) is published in the Gazette before 1 January 2005, the inquiry certificate day is taken to be 1 January 2005.

(6) The Minister must cause a copy of the report of the inquiry established under subsection (1) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after receiving the report.

We are moving this amendment to address what we regard as a shortcoming in the ACIS billsâthat is, that an inquiry into ACIS will not be held until 2005 when the automotive industry is already faced with a harsher, lower tariff environment. The 2005 review was made known by the government in a joint statement by the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the then minister for industry. They stated, on 5 June 1997, that there will be a review in 2005. What we have been saying from the outset is that this is an inappropriate time to have the review. Commonsense dictates that the review must occur before the tariff cuts occur to ensure that the automotive industry is ready in one way or another to face the challenges of the new regime.

When we raised this point in the House of Representatives, the government gave an entirely unsatisfactory response. They said that they did not need an amendment about an inquiry because the government might have an inquiry anyway. This is not good enough. The inquiry may be scheduled way too late in the process. Furthermore, nobody knows what sort of inquiry it will be. Nobody knows whether the parliament will receive the report from that inquiry. Nobody knows whether the public will get a chance to make submissions, whether the industry will get a chance to make submissions, whether the communities affected by this very important, regionally based industry will get a chance to make submissions, or whether the state governmentsâparticularly of South Australia and Victoriaâwill get a chance to make submissions.

That is why we think a proper inquiry needs to be legislated nowâheld before the tariff changes take place so that all those participants in the car industry can be certain that they will have the opportunity to put their views before an informed decision is made. If this does not happen, it is simply not possible to know what is going to follow these transitional arrangementsâor if changes do occur, precisely how these transitional arrangements are going to continue beyond 2005. We do not want $2 billion worth of support to just fall straight off the edge of a cliffâafter five yearsâto zero support. That is what this parliament is being asked to vote for at the moment. This is an unreasonable proposition. Our amendment is one that the government could and should accept. It is the `was not made here' syndrome. It should not hesitate simply because the opposition is proposing it. If there is a change of government, Labor will hold an inquiry. It will be public and will happen in 2003. What we want is for the parliament to ensure that, whether there is a change of government or not, that inquiry takes place.

talk.start.para: âI rise to say that most of the comments and reasons for supporting the ALP amendments were outlined last night, and I do not wish to address them any further other than to indicate our support.

âMay I express the government's profound disappointment that the opposition, supported by the Democrats, are persisting with these amendments to this package of legislation, which they unsuccessfully moved in the House of Representatives. The amendments essentially seek to defer the proposed reduction in the tariff to 10 per centâto take place in 2005âuntil there is another review of automotive policy settings. We have some problems with that proposition, which have been outlined in the House and by me publicly, but I think they need to be restated.

speech.para: Fundamentally, in a procedural sense, we are again putting this industry into limbo. As the opposition members have said, what this industry needs most of all is certainty and security. This package delivers that, and a fundamental part of the package is that we freeze the tariff at 15 per cent next year and then it drops to 10 per cent in 2005. They are fundamental pillars of this package, a package which the industry has supported solidly since it was announced nearly 2Â½ years ago. But here we have the opposition undermining confidence in this industry by seeking to remove one of the fundamental pillars of this integrated policy package. I want to emphasise that point.

This is an integrated policy package which does provide $2 billion in support for this industry, on the very premise that the tariffs will drop to 10 per cent in the year 2005. That is the logic of the scheme: we are providing assistance, to the tune of $2 billion, to enable the industry to make this transition to a 10 per cent tariff. You remove the whole basis for that assistance package if you remove one of its pillars, and that is a 10 per cent rate; remembering that even at 10 per cent, in the year 2005âmore than five years from nowâthis industry will still be receiving a higher level of tariff protection than virtually any other manufacturing industry in this country, after five years of very generous support from the government.

We have had review after review of this industry. This policy package which we are bringing is the result of a very extensive Industry Commission inquiry which looked at policy settings through to 2005. As I have said, the industry strongly supports this package as is and wants it passed by this parliament forthwith so that it can get on and plan its investmentsâmultibillion dollar investmentsâon the basis of a secure and certain policy framework.

I am extremely disappointed that the opposition and the Democrats are undermining confidence in this industry and further delaying investment decisions by industry by putting up amendments which they know full well we cannot and will not accept. So this bill will have to go back to the House of Representatives, and there the government will reject these amendments. That is not going to do the industry any favours at all, and the basis on which these amendments are being put runs counter to the whole framework and integrity of this package. We do oppose the amendments and we oppose them for very good reasons.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Conroy's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Bill, as amended, agreed to.
ACIS (UNEARNED CREDIT LIABILITY) BILL 1999
The bill.
Bill agreed to.
CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT (ACIS IMPLEMENTATION) BILL 1999
The bill.
Amendments (by Senator Conroy)âby leaveâproposed:
(1) Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 5), before item 1, insert:
Insert:
inquiry certificate day has the meaning given by section 117 of the ACIS Administration Act 1999 .
(2) Schedule 1, item 1, page 3 (after line 9), omit "1 January 2005", substitute "the inquiry certificate day".
(3) Schedule 1, item 2, page 3 (after line 14), omit "1 January 2005", substitute "the inquiry certificate day".
(4) Schedule 1, item 3, page 4 (after line 5), omit "1 January 2005", substitute "the inquiry certificate day".
(5) Schedule 1, item 4, page 4 (after line 10), omit "1 January 2005", substitute "the inquiry certificate day".
(6) Schedule 1, item 5, page 5 (after line 4), omit "1 January 2005", substitute "the inquiry certificate day".
(7) Schedule 1, item 6, page 5 (after line 9), omit "1 January 2005", substitute "the inquiry certificate day".
(8) Schedule 1, item 8, page 7 (after line 2), omit "31 December 2004", substitute "the day before the inquiry certificate day".
(9) Schedule 1, item 8, page 10 (after line 1), omit "1 January 2005", substitute "the inquiry certificate day".

talk.start.para: âI have really put down the arguments against these opposition amendments and expressed my great disappointment on behalf of the government that the opposition are moving these amendments and further delaying this very important assistance package to the automotive industry. But I do want to draw attention to the position as put by the Federation of Automotive Products Manufacturers, a key industry body in this area, which has written to both the shadow minister, Mr McMullan, and the Democrats spokesman on this matter, Senator Ridgeway, as follows:

speech.para: This agreementâ
that is, the ACIS legislation packageâ

to which FAPM and all four car assemblers are party to, includes a freeze of the tariff of 15 per cent until 30 December 2004 whereafter the tariff will fall to 10 per cent, together with an appropriate scheme to replace export facilitation. In our viewâ
that is, the view of the Federation of Automotive Products Manufacturersâ
the legislation presently before the Senate will be important in driving investment and creating a more competitive automotive industry.
We are concerned that any delay in the Senate's consideration of this matter will disrupt this industry's plans to invest.
We therefore seek your support in ensuring the timely passage of this legislation through the Parliament.

That is the position of a key industry player, representing the thousands of workers in this industry who are dependent on further investment by the major companies, asking the opposition and the Democrats not to do what they are doing but to get on with the business and support this legislative package so that companies can start investing, knowing what the environment will be over the next five years. But, of course, no, the opposition and, regrettably, the Democrats want to play politics with this and further delay and create uncertainty and confusion in this industry.

We have told the parliament and the nation why it is important that this package should go through as is. We have industry support for it. I have already indicated that although this is a matter for a future governmentâand there are two elections due before this scheme expiresâfrom my point of view I have no objection to the review of post-2005 arrangements commencing prior to 2005. I have no objection to that whatsoever and I put that matter on the record. But it is vital that we not send any mixed signals about what the tariff rate will be as of 1 January 2005. It will be a 10 per cent tariff rate but, obviously, we will want to review that to see exactly what should happen with respect to tariffs and any further assistance to this industry post 2005. As I say, that review, as far as I am concerned, could commence before 2005. We do not want to legislate to that effect and we do not want to send any signals that the tariff rate will not fall to 10 per cent. The industry needs to know what tariff regime it will operate under. We need this bill to go through now on that basis.

talk.start.para: âAs a matter of response, I again make it clear that the Democrats are happy to support the amendments. The point I make is that I do not think that all the sides of politics disagree on the outcome; it is more a case of quibbling about dates. Essentially, in my view, it is a case of accountability in public policy making. Clearly, if it is a case of looking at competitiveness and innovation in the industry, let us not quibble about dates. If the minister and the government are serious about what they see as reform, there is still an opportunity for that to occur.

speech.para: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

ACIS Administration Bill 1999 reported with an amendment; ACIS (Unearned Credit Liability) Bill 1999 reported without amendments; Customs Tariff Amendment (ACIS Implementation) Bill 1999 reported with amendments; report adopted.

subdebate.1.para: Bills (on motion by Senator Minchin) read a third time.

debateinfo.title: CORPORATE LAW ECONOMIC REFORM PROGRAM BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 21 June, on motion by Senator Ellison:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased that the government has got itself organised over that side of the chamber. Senator Ian Campbell, I am looking forward to your contribution on the Corporate Law Economic Reform Program Bill 1998 , which I know you have followed very closely.

speech.para: The government has made a lot of claims about this bill, but it will not admit that it will weaken existing regulations on prudential and fiduciary responsibilities of those involved in the governance of corporations. The bill will undermine rules designed to promote transparency, accountability and equity. It compromises market integrity. The opposition have considered this bill with an open mind. In arriving at our position, we believe that we have asked the right questions, including: do the propositions encourage managers to be accountable to shareholders through consultation and disclosure in a timely manner, do the propositions help to define the role of the board of directors as active participants in the governance of the corporation, and do the propositions help to define shareholders' rights and treat all shareholders of the same class equally?

No doubt there are positive elements to this bill, such as the fundraising proposals and the revamp of the takeover panel, but the negatives outweigh the positives. There are substantial shortcomings to this bill.
