There is nothing that senators can do to stop the dope from selling their car, their house or their shares too cheaply, but if a sensible person was made an offer on their house that they thought may not be the best offer, they would probably ring up a real estate agent and ask them if they could get a better price. I have to say that most people who are offered a price for their shares will ring up a merchant bank or a stockbroker and say, `This bloke has just offered me 30 cents for my shares. What do you think?' That stockbroker will quickly try to find someone who can do better, because he will get a commission out of it, so the concept that you get rid of the auctionâthat you get rid of a market for sharesâis absolute baloney.

I believe that the mandatory bid, contrary to what its opponents have been saying, is in fact very much in the shareholders' interests, because, with the reforms to the panel, ensuring that litigation is reduced and that the panel quickly resolves disputes and lets the takeovers move on, combined with the reforms to the capital gains tax treatment of scrip for scrip takeovers, you will find, with the mandatory bid, that small shareholders will have the benefit of far more offers for their shares. That is what we are aiming for.

That covers some of the areas. We will have to go into a lot more detail in the committee stage but I very sincerely thank all other senators for their contributions and commend this most excellent bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:
That consideration of this bill in the committee of the whole be made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

debateinfo.title: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 22 September, on motion by Senator Patterson:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI am obliged to the Senate for granting leave for me to speak on the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999 . The second reading speech, which was incorporated, I believe was in terms of 1998 figures. Of course, it should be now couched in 1999 final figures to match the explanatory memorandum which was tabled. The $36.3 million in relation to literacy and numeracy should now be $38.3 million. The $26.4 million to extend funding for the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools strategy should now be $27.9 million. In relation to $10.1 million under the capital grants program, that should now be $10.3 million. And in relation to short-term emer gency assistance, the $1.9 million should now be $2 million. I hope that assists the Senate accordingly.
âI move:

speech.para: At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a) using the important issue of literacy in a cynical political fashion; and
(b) failing to provide government schools with additional resources in line with its increased expenditure for the non-government sector".

The States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999 seeks to give effect to a number of budget measures which, as has just been indicated by the minister, actually changed from the time at which the bill was introduced. I note that the government is chopping and changing with its legislative program. While the opposition seeks to assist the government in the processing of legislation, it would serve the parliament a great deal if the government could actually provide a little bit of notice so that speakers could prepare to come on in the chamber. Notwithstanding the fact that the government has clearly mismanaged its program so completelyâagainâI think it is important to point out that this is a bill that seeks to provide $38 million for the National Literacy and Numeracy Plan and for the literacy improvement strategies for the middle years of schooling, and $27.9 million for the year 2000 to extend funding for the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools strategy.

I think everyone now recognises that Dr Kemp's grand plan for self-promotion and self-aggrandisement via the literacy issue has run out of puff. He has been sidelined by the announcements in August this year by New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and the ACT that they were undertaking nationally comparable tests, with Queensland to participate next year. The fact that these statesâand only one had a Labor government at the timeâwent out of their way to exclude the federal minister shows the contempt with which those who actually run schools view Dr Kemp's political grandstanding on such an important issue.

The initiative shows the value of cooperation and bipartisanship over the bullying and headline grabbing strategies that Dr Kemp has been pursuing. Dr Kemp would have us believe that he invented concern about literacy, whereas basic skills testing has been happening in New South Wales since 1987 and in Victoria and South Australia since 1995, well before Dr Kemp actually became a minister. We never hear a single word from the federal minister about the Keating government's Early Literacy Program or the fact that it was Labor which set up the National Schools English Literacy Survey, whose results Dr Kemp manipulates so shamelessly.

On 14 September 1997, after locking the states into silence on the issue of the survey results until Monday, 15 September, Dr Kemp appeared on the Sixty Minutes program to pre-empt the states and put his own spin on the survey results and his interpretation of them. The education ministers from Victoria, Queensland and Tasmaniaâand I repeat that at the time all had conservative governmentsâco-authored a media release which said:
The ministers call on Dr Kemp to cease his cynical political stunts.

The then Minister for Education in the Kennett government, Mr Phil Gude, called Dr Kemp a `spin doctor'. As recently as 9 August this year, Mr Gude said on a Four Corners program, and I hope the minister takes particular note of this advice:

Well, I think what he was clearly trying to do was to gain a profile on an issue, and I thought it was not cricket, if you like . . . to use the kids, use the teachers, use the profession in that way.
That is what Mr Gude said. He also said:
I've found in my life that honesty has never got me into any trouble.

What an extraordinary revelation. It is a pity Dr Kemp did not hear that message. I might say that it is a pity that a few others in the Victorian government did not hear that message before the election results in that state in recent weeks. The interviewer went on to say:
You accused him at the time of deliberately and mischievously manipulating data to portray literacy at a perilous level.
Mr Gude said:
Yes, I did . . . because I believe that's what was done.

The fact is that there is very little gloss left on this issue for the ministerâor indeed on any other issue for this minister. He has been exposed on the literacy issue. His incompetent handling of the Job Network led to his demotion following the last election. He followed that with promises of a research green paper which was six months late and which turned out to be not worth waiting for. He has been prodded into action by the opposition on issues like the various vocational education and training rorts and, of course, on the various scandals which are being revealed in education for overseas students.

talk.start.para: âOne college.

âThirty colleges, Minister. I look forward to you providing the same level of attention to those other colleges that have been named in this chamber that you have in terms of the National College of Australia. I note that it took you the better part of three months to find out about itâan extraordinary level of negligence by this government. On top of that, the minister has saddled this government with his disastrousâ
âSix weeks.

âThat is not quite the case. The college collapsed in June. My concerns to the government were registered well before I asked a question in this chamber. The Prime Minister, on 23 September, was so restrained in his praise of the education minister and he found the words that he did only by scrabbling for something positive to say about various members of his frontbench. Quite clearly, what has happened is that Dr Kemp has lost the confidence of the Prime Minister, and I believe he has lost the confidence of most people.
âThat's why he's still the minister for education.

âOnly just. We will wait and see just how long that lasts. I also suggest that the National Asian Languages and Stud ies in Australian Schools programâor NALSASâis another policy area where Dr Kemp would have us believe that history began on the day he was sworn in as minister. He is fulsome in his praise for this program and its value in developing cultural understanding and skills for participation in the global economy, but he never mentions that it was established under the Keating government, with the strong support of the Goss government in Queensland.

speech.para: Other Labor initiatives which Dr Kemp has sought to claim credit for are the Australian Student Traineeship Foundation and the Jobs Pathway program. Regarding the latter, he actually said in parliament on 25 August that the Jobs Pathway program had been established by the coalition. Dr Kemp tries to take credit for good ideas. Given that he has so few of them himself, you can understand why he is so happy to steal those of others. His contribution to policy development has been zero. He is driven solely by an ideological obsession with privatisation, cost cutting and union bashing.

I now turn to the issue of teacher professional development, for which the budget included an announcement of $77.7 million over four years. The minister said in parliament on 2 September that the money was provided in Appropriation Bill (No. 1). However, that was not the case. Appropriation bills are for only one year at a time. So $15 million of the $78 million has been legislated for. I ask why we are not able to see the funds in the States Grants Act, through which the vast bulk of school funding is channelled and which legislates funds for four years. It is important for us to see where this money is legislated. It is appropriate that the minister, in his concluding remarks, explains to us exactly where that money is legislated. Is it because no descriptions of individual programs are now included in the appropriation bills, and this initiative could disappear next year or the year after, with very little evidence and before the promised $78 million has been delivered? I challenge the minister to deliver on the rest of the promises, to legislate for the remaining $62 million and to do so in an open and accountable way. Final ly, I should point out that the funding of teacher professional development is yet another Labor initiative which the Howard government has now endorsed and adopted, having cut the program in previous budgets.

This bill deals with initiatives in school funding announced in this year's budget. On the subject of school funding and the budget, I have some quite serious issues that I would like to pursue. I note that the officers are present. I think it has become an annual event to go through some of these questions. It is obvious that, at major expense, the Howard government has sent to all schoolsâgovernment and non-governmentâboxes and boxes of glossy brochures full of self-promotions, accompanied by a covering letter to parents which has sought to request the principals to distribute government propaganda. The minister should be able to tell us how much of the taxpayers' money was used in this outrageous exercise. I am sure that at the committee stage of the bill we will be able to pursue this question. I also ask whether he can tell us how many of the principals advised that they were not distributing the material. I turn to the content of the letters and brochures. The brochure accompanying the letter to the government school parents claims thatâand I quote:
Direct Federal funding for government schools has risen between 1996 and 2000 by 25 per cent, or $382 million.

The reality, however, is very different. The fact is that costs in schooling have risen by 12 per cent since 1996 and enrolments have increased. The minister clearly wants parents to believe that government schools have more Commonwealth money to spend on more things than they need.

Let us see whether we can set the record straight. Once adjusted for cost increases, my calculations indicate that expenditure will increase by only one-hundredth of what Dr Kemp claimsâthat is, $3 million. That is about $1.50 for each student. The fact is that a dollar is only worth what it will buy. If someone had a dollar to cover the cost of a loaf of bread five years ago, they would now need $1.30 to buy the same item. When we give a person $1.30 that does not mean that they are provided with a 30 per cent funding increase. In real terms, there has been no increase. Looking at the dollars in real terms, Commonwealth funding increases by about $3 million between 1996 and 2000. But what happens when we adjust for enrolment increases? For this I used the funded enrolments used by DETYA for each of the years, in order to maintain consistency.

My calculations indicate that, on a per student basis, direct Commonwealth funding has fallen from just over $606 in 1996 to less than $598 four years later. Let me repeat that: direct Commonwealth funding per government school student actually declines over the period 1996 to 2000. So much for this government's claims of increased funding.

The government seeks to defend itself by claiming that the bulk of funding for government schools is provided by the states and territories. It then goes on to claim that the pool of money from which states and territories provide funding for schools is growing in real terms. The Prime Minister told parliament on 13 May this year:

The major call on the budgets of most state governmentsânot the only call, of course, but one of the major callsâis government education. In the coming financial year, the financial assistance grants going to the Australian states will rise by something close to five per cent in real terms. It is therefore stark obvious that all of the governments of the Australian states will have more resources to fund government schools.

The claim that in 1999-2000 Commonwealth financial assistance grants to the states and territories will rise by almost five per cent in real terms was also repeated in answer to Senate estimates question No. E2, which I asked on 8 June this year. I can only presume that the same level of bodgie advice that has been provided to the Prime Minister has been provided to the Senate estimates committee. In Dr Kemp's open letter to parents, which I referred to earlier, he stated:
The 1999 Commonwealth Budget provided a 3 per cent real increase in Financial Assistance Grants to the States which they can use to further increase funding for governments schools.

So, is the increase five per cent or three per cent? The answer is: none of the above. Budget Paper No. 3 states that financial assistance grants, or FAGs, have been maintained this year in real per capita terms; that is, they have been adjusted for price increases and population growth only. There is no additional, discretionary funding available for states to spend on schools or anything else. The same point has to be made again and again because it is quite clear that the departmental officials have not got the message. They keep repeating the same errors and the same advice to government. One can only presume that it is either the department providing bodgie advice to government or bodgie advice is being provided by government to the Australian people. We look forward to an explanation of which it is.

The second point is that this is the same government which told us repeatedly that its $1.6 billion cut to FAGs in 1996 would have no impact on state spending on government schools. So an increase means more money but a cut means no less moneyâan extraordinary jump in logic. This is the nature of the propaganda that we have seen coming out of this government. It is very interesting mathematics but meaningless in many ways because the claim of an increase in FAGs simply is wrong. However, the government has a second string to its bow in seeking to defend itself against government school funding critics, and the second string is just as flimsy as the first. The open letter to parents says:
The Government's New Tax System will also deliver to the States significant increases which can allow more funds to be directed to government schools.

Official government estimates are that GST revenue will not even match the current level of FAGs for at least three years. So the Commonwealth has had to give a written assurance to the states and territories that it will provide additional funds as necessary to top up any shortfall, which may well be on an indefinite basis.

There is no justification for the Commonwealth to reduce the proportion of its funding for government schools ahead of a demonstrable improvement in the position of the states and territories in terms of the available discretionary resources to make up such a shortfall. Of course, that is exactly what is happening. The answer to Senate estimates question E3, which I asked on 8 June this year, shows that the proportion of direct Commonwealth funding going to government schools will fall to 35.3 per cent in 2003, down from 41.5 per cent in 1996, and that is before one extra cent of GST revenueâover and above what they would have received under the old systemâwill have been received by the states.

What we are seeing is a pattern of deceit being exercised by this government in so far as it makes claims of increasing moneys being made available to the states and claims about increased moneys being available for education in this country when, in fact, the opposite is the case. The government's defence on these issues has no substance. The people of Australia need to understand that the Howard government is actively working to undermine public education in this country.

The ALP, in contrast, is happy to support additional resources going to needy non-government schools, but there must be extra resources given to the government schools in line with those additional resources going to private sector schools, and funding initiatives must be presented in a balanced way. Dr Kemp tries to tell us that the government does not favour one school sector over another, but the fact is, as shadow ministerâ
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being 6.50 p.m., the debate is interrupted and we move to consideration of government documents. There are 38 government documents listed for consideration on today's Order of Business , and there is a limit of half an hour for their consideration. To expedite the consideration of the documents, I propose, with the concurrence of honourable senators, to call the documents in groups of five. Documents not called on today will remain on the Notice Paper .

subdebateinfo.title: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

In speaking to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet 1989-99 annual report, it is probably no coincidence that I find some of the areas outlined in it most interesting, particularly the Office of the Status of Women, given the announcement by that office in the last week or so in regard to funding. This report provides quite an insight into what the Office of the Status of Women was like in the previous year. A number of elements are worth drawing the Senate's attention to. No doubt, with keen interest, I will be seeking to continue my remarks on this later.

In particular, the report mentions a total of 37 organisations applying for funding last year under the national women's non-government organisation funding programs and says that, of those 37 organisations, 13 applications were found to be ineligible. Obviously nine did not get any funding at all, but the interesting thing, in light of this week's decision and the debate which happened in the House of Representatives this afternoon, is that last year, of these remaining applicants, 13 organisations were considered to meet the criteria to a high degree and were funded to a total of $500,000. Of course, we know that, in light of this week's decision, those 13 organisations have now been reduced to only three and they will be sharing in $300,000.

I also notice in this report that last year's women's roundtable meeting held in Parliament House over two days in August was attended by 50 women's non-government organisations. The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women also held five regional roundtable meetings. People should be aware that next week the Office of the Status of Women's roundtable is happening again, but what is notable about next week is those who have not been invited. Only 20 women's non-government organisations have been invited, so what happened to the other 30? They got a letter saying, `You're not coming', or `Don't bother to come next week.' In light of this annual report, it will be very interesting to see what next year's annual report produces for us. It provides a great area for further explanation during the Senate estimates round coming up in a couple of weeks.

This report also says, under the status of women, that responsibility for monitoring the implementation of Australia's obligations under the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women rests with the Office of the Status of Women. But it does not go on to say how they have done that; whether, in fact, they have done it; how comprehensively they have done it; or whether they have not done it all. It just states, as a matter of fact, that they have responsibility for it. We all know that, and I find that this annual report is fairly deficient in providing us with information about how they have gone about it.

They also say they are responsible for representing the government at relevant international forums. One will await the next estimates in December to hear how well the Office of the Status of Women was represented quite recently at the ILO, where the Australian government suggested that women in this country should be subjected to pregnancy tests prior to being employed. I notice that there is no mention of that sort of policy or that thought from the government in this annual report. There are a number of statements in this report that are not backed up by either evidence or claims about exactly what the Office of the Status of Women is doing. This is not surprising for those of us who have been following the path of the OSW in recent years.

In my remaining time, I think it is also worthy to note on page 41 a statement about the Alice Springs to Darwin Railway. In view of the limited time we have tonight, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

The reason I would like the Senate to take note of this document tonight is that this is the Reserve Bank's Equal Employment Opportunity Annual Report , and we rarely get an opportunity to highlight some of the elements within the workplace that provide a plan for equal employment opportunity. We should take note of some of the initiatives and compliment the Reserve Bank of Australia not only for printing this but also on the content. In the brief time I have had today to look at this report, I felt that, while there can always be many improvements in terms of equal employment opportunity, this document is a good start. In their report they say that, as part of their EEO program, a new EEO plan was developed to cover the period from July 1997 to June 1999. This report seeks to outline the advances that they have made in this. As part of this program, the proportion of women at management levels within their organisation has continued to rise, although they make note that it is particularly women who are yet to take up the options of training and retraining, particularly in some of the lower paid classifications.

One of the areas that are most worthy of highlighting is their intent to improve the rate of long-term retention of women following parental leave. In 1998-99, the return rate of women from parental leave was the lowest since 1989-90. Through their plan, the Reserve Bank have sought to improve that. The evidence in this report shows that they have had some success.

They say in their report that the low rate of return was largely guaranteed due to restructuring over the past year, and that the bank has sought to improve return rates in the future with changes negotiated in its productivity bargaining agreement of 1999-2000. So, despite some of the evidence that the government would like us to believe, here we have a successful department working well with the union through a productivity agreement, not individual contracts, that has brought about positive changes in the workplace. These changes will limit parental leave absences to 12 months but with the provision of assured access to part-time work on return for a minimum period of six months.

They have done an evaluation of the representation of women in courses of study during the year and they are honest enough to say that there is still some underrepresentation of women at the lower classification levels but that the gender gap has narrowed in most of the classification levels. They have set out a range of family friendly initiatives that they have sought to introduce, such as producing a booklet on managing people with disabilities. They have also looked at their staff selection and recruitment procedures. They have taken steps to enhance the integrity of the selection panel arrangements. They have revised their traineeship program. They have encouraged their supervisors to assess their employees' training and development needs through performance appraisal processes, and they have introduced self-paced learning which has provided staff with options for development which can be organised around work and home commitments.

This report also details their initiatives in relation to salary sacrificing for child care, job sharing, part-time leave and a carer's leave trial. It is important that from time to time we note that there are sections of the government that are seeking to improve family friendly practices and implementing EEO plans for women in the work force. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: The following government document was considered:
Telstra Corporation LimitedâReport for 1998-99. Motion to take note of document moved by Senator Crossin. Debate adjourned till Thursday at general business, Senator Crossin in continuation.

talk.start.para: âOrder! There being no further consideration of government documents, I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âI rise this evening to make a few brief remarks on matters pertaining to the continuing humanitarian efforts in particular in East Timor. Senators would knowâas I suspect I have been telling them ad nauseam since my returnâthat I was a member of the Australian Observer Delegation for the Popular Consultation in East Timor. Because much of the post Popular Consultation preparation for humanitarian efforts was being carried out in Darwin in the Northern Territory, I undertook a visit to Darwin at the end of the last sitting week. There were large numbers of international aid workers based there at that stage doing an enormous amount of coordination and work on preparations for the full humanitarian effort in East Timor.

speech.para: I undertook the visit to Darwin as the President of the UNICEF Parliamentary Association. I thought it would be a very valuable opportunity to see what UNICEF was doing and, although one cannot always do a great deal, to offer at least moral support in this context. I want to place on record my sincere appreciation and grateful thanks to Ms Mirna Yacoub, a UNICEF program officer usually based in Sydney, who was my guide and highly informative adviser for the visit. She had made an exceptional effort to set up the UNICEF presence in Darwin from effectively a blank sheet. In doing that, she had to establish some effective office operations and assist a number of international UNICEF officers in their efforts in East Timor.

She arranged a very valuable meeting for me with some of those people, including Mr Brian Clear, who is usually based in Pyongyang, Mr Buddy Tillet, usually based in New York, and Mr Mark Thomas, who I believe is usually based in Bangkok. We were able to discuss UNICEF's operations in this crisis context as it is playing out in East Timor. Mr Tillet had just spent 10 or 12 days in East Timor as part of the initial operations. He had seen the initial roll-out of aid. He described for me the fly-over of many of the western areas of East Timor. His particularly vivid descriptions of areas that our observer delegation had visited brought home to me in particular the extent of the destruction wrought in some areas.

I also, over an extended period, visited the area known as the `tent city', which had housed so many of the East Timorese refugees flown into Darwin out of the very difficult circumstances in Dili just after the Popular Consultation. The commander of the tent city was a Northern Territory police officer, Mick Heythuysen, a very impressive person who had an excellent operation under way in the tent city. I was particularly impressed with the efforts of both government and non-government groups in that operation. At that stage, there were still more than 200 refugees there. There were many families with young children, and one can only imagine the trauma that that sort of experience causes. There was a significant number of Northern Territory government public servants supporting that process. There was a fantastic medical clinic very impressively set up within the tent city.

talk.start.para: âA great bunch of things.

âI am supporting that sincerely, Senator Crossin. The registration and tracking of the refugees was undertaken with an excellent custom designed computer program for which, I understand, another young officer from the Northern Territory Police was responsible. The tents of the tent city were set up by the Army. There was a very impressive kitchen, which had entailed some very valuable East Timorese expert supervision of the caterers to ensure that the food was appropriate for the refugees and their families.

speech.para: A very important component of this whole process was the operation of the local Catholic clergy in holding mass regularly and enabling the East Timorese to worship as they wished. The entertainment and amusements for the children were diverse and very valuable for them in terms of diverting their attention from a difficult circumstance and minimising, if at all possible, the trauma they had undergone. As part of that there was a very heavy involvement of the Northern Territory's East Timorese community, in ensuring that their country men and women and their families were well looked after. And of course there was involvement of Commonwealth agenciesâin particular the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs.

One of the things that the commander in particular showed me in some detail was the map that they had placed in the registration area for the refugees, which very clearly showed them how close Darwin was to East Timor. The dislocation that one feels must be extraordinary, and to actually be able to visualise that distance, they said, was very important to the refugees and very valuable for them.

Everybody to whom I spoke in Darwin, without exception, noted the extraordinary job, the extraordinary contribution, of both the Northern Territory government and the City of Darwin Council to this entire process. It was not just in relation to the tent city, but in relation to the whole effort of moving humanitarian aid into East Timor from Darwin. It was a ringing message. The internationals present in Darwin could not thank Australia enoughâno matter where they came from, no matter what their involvement.

UNICEF also took me to visit the two particular warehouses where stores were located before transportation to East Timor. A UNAMET worker who had previously been in East Timor for three or four months was coordinating that process. You can imagine trying to do that for a diversity of agencies, a diversity of governments and with a diversity of methods of transportation. It was an enormous challenge for him and for those involved to do thatâby air or sea, whether it was UNICEF, CARITAS, Medecins Sans Frontieres or the World Food Program. We are talking about food and emergency rations, particularly for babies, about water containers and about the practical basics of office infrastructure, like bits and pieces of photocopiers and faxes, which begged the question about the use of power. Those warehouses were well set up and well coordinated to achieve all of that.

I had the opportunity also to visit the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, again in space donated by the government of the Northern Territory, where there were dozens of people from all over the world and from every conceivable international agency operating in that area. I received a briefing from the World Food Program, and we have seen in recent days many of the pictures of the distribution of rice in East Timor. Its implementing partner, World Vision, was working on that. Just to give some perspective on that process, the World Food Program plans to feed over 600,000 people for six months. This is not two or three weeksâor two or three months, for that matter. The World Food Program and its partners are coordinating to provide food for work, seed protection, small-scale infrastructure rehabilitation projects and general supporting guidance in the promotion of food security for the East Timorese.

At that level there was a very impressive level of coordination, of which I would like to make note. In the Senate references committee inquiry into East Timor, many witnesses were concerned about how and whether aid provision will be effectively coordinated. I left that particular day in Darwin with a very positive impression of the agencies working well togetherâboth UN and non-UN. One imagines that there are always healthy tensions involved in this process when you bring together a group of people who have never worked together before, but it seemed to me that OCHA was doing a very good job at making sure people did work together. The day I was there, for example, I witnessed the establishment of a couple of meetings that were part of that whole process of making sure thatâin colloquial termsâthe left hand knew what the right hand was doing.

It was a particularly useful visit at the time, and I was very grateful for the time of the UNICEF people in particular. We have spoken again with UNICEF this week to see how matters have progressed. In terms of East Timor itself, UNICEF has now established a formal office in Dili. They have seven individuals working out of that office and they have started the distribution of the most important components of their programs, which, in an emergency situation like this, are obviously in support of, particularly, mothers and children. The goods that I saw in the warehouses in Darwin have been effectively transported and distributed, more importantly, throughout East Timor.

There are ongoing problems. In simple terms they are issues of security, which are affecting all operations in East Timor; issues of suppliesâbasic office supplies and the basic supplies of everyday life; and issues of accommodationâthe more staff one has, the more difficult that becomes. Food is still being sent in for the UNICEF staff in East Timor. The electricity and water situations are best described as variable. Most importantly, the efforts of UNICEF and other international organisations are beginning to bear fruit. They are very productive efforts, and Australia has made in its efforts through its preparatory work in Darwin and in more general terms an enormous and effective contribution to that entire process. I place again on record my thanks to UNICEF in the Northern Territory for assisting with my visit.

talk.start.para: âTonight I rise to speak on something that I feel quite strongly about, not only because of its effect on me personally but also because it has recently been recognised as an issue of national importance. I refer to the medical condition of asthma, being recognised during Australia's National Asthma Week.

speech.para: It is hard to ignore the significance of asthma as a health issue in Australia. Asthma affects one in four children, around one in seven adolescents and one in 10 adults. What is more, its prevalence is on the rise in Australia. With over two million asthma sufferers in this country, there would be few people who did not know someone who is an asthma sufferer. Asthma has had a major impact on our use of medical services in Australia. It is the most common reason for hospital admission among young children and one of the top 10 reasons that Australians visit their GP. It has been estimated that asthma costs the Australian community in excess of $700 million. But its importance is not limited to its impact on our health resources. Asthma is a very stressful condition. It causes major disruption to the lives of sufferers, their friends and loved ones. This is particularly the case for parents of asthmatic children. Asthma is a major cause of school and work absenteeism and can seriously affect the quality of the lives of its sufferers.

I read recently that evidence is also emerging that asthmatic children suffer more sleep disturbance, which can affect memory and concentration. As someone with a passionate interest and belief in the importance of education to children's futures, I find this evidence worrying. I believe that it strengthens the case for making the management of asthma a priority. Last but not least, asthma remains an important cause of premature deaths in Australia. Over 700 people died from asthma in Australia in 1997. With an estimated 60 per cent of these deaths being preventable, improving the management of asthma in our community is a goal few could argue with.

In June of this year, the Minister for Health was asked about the government's intentions in relation to the health problem of asthma. In responding to this question, the minister outlined the government's commitment to a national campaign aimed at improving the management of asthma, gathering information about its causes and increasing asthma awareness in the community. At this time, the minister unveiled his plan to make asthma Australia's sixth national health priority, also referring to the fact that not all state and territory governments supported the move.

Following this announcement, I wrote to the Northern Territory's Minister for Health, Steve Dunham, to seek his position on the proposal. In his response the minister did not commit himself to whether or not he would support the proposal to make asthma the sixth national health priority at the next health ministers' meeting. However, he did raise a number of issues which suggest that he was not entirely enthusiastic about it. He had three major reservations about asthma being made a national health priority. His first reservation was about focusing on a single disease rather than seeking to address chronic diseases more generally, for example chronic respiratory diseases. His argument was based on the fact that many preventable chronic diseases have common risk factors. The Northern Territory has recently adopted a chronic preventable disease strategy for this reason, and I support such a move, but I want to return later to the Territory government's lack of commitment to dealing with an important risk factor in asthma and other preventable chronic diseases, if I have the time.

The second point that the Northern Territory health minister raised against making asthma a national health priority was related to the asthma management. The minister stated in his letter that general practitioners carried the main responsibility for asthma management. This ignores the significant role that the public health system does and should play in the management of asthma, as does the well-known and well-publicised Asthma Foundation. For example, for the 1998-99 year, 20 per cent of all paediatric presentations to casualty in Territory hospitals for respiratory problems were related to asthma. Of adults attending a casualty department, 26 per cent of those seeking emergency help with a respiratory problem had asthma or suspected asthma. So it is important to remember that state and territory governments have a significant responsibility for emergency care for asthma patients.

The health minister also argued that asthma is not a particularly serious health problem in the Territory's indigenous community. He stated that rates of asthma among both Aboriginal adults and children are lower than rates of asthma for non-Aboriginal Territorians. Last month a national asthma conference was held in Darwin, with keynote addresses from Northern Territory experts addressing this very issue. It would seem that these people are less certain than the minister that asthma rates are lower in the indigenous community, particularly in the case of adults. In any event, the relationship between asthma and other chronic respiratory diseases which cause premature death is a long way from being fully understood. But refining our understanding and management of all respiratory disease is surely vital, particularly given the fact that Aboriginal women in the Northern Territory are around 60 times more likely to die from chronic obstructive lung disease than non-Aboriginal women in the Territory.

As I stated earlier, the chronic disease strategy adopted by the Northern Territory government has undoubted merit because it addresses a number of the common contributing factors to health problems such as cardiovascular disease and chronic respiratory disease. But, as I have already said in this place some weeks ago in an adjournment debate, the Northern Territory government has thus far failed to take sufficient responsibility in addressing one of the major contributors to this problem and a major problem for asthma sufferers. That is cigarette smoking. During National Heart Week this year, the Territory government's unsatisfactory performance on addressing juvenile smoking received considerable attention. It is pleasing to see that the Territory government is now addressing the issue of the sale of tobacco to minors a bit more vigorously, though. Another development since I spoke in this place last on the subject is the Northern Territory government's release of a draft tobacco strategy for 1999-2001. This document contains many existing methods to reduce the rate of smoking and its harmful effects. There are also new strategies to reduce smoking among Aboriginal people and young Territorians. These new strategies involve education, health promotion and creating greater awareness of the Territory's existing law under which the sale of tobacco to minors is an offence.

But we know that education strategies are not enough to reduce smoking and its harmful effects in the community. We know that governments need to go further than merely encouraging people to stop smoking or trying to convince them not to start in the first place. Unfortunately, in the area of tobacco legislation the Northern Territory government is seriously lagging. For example, so far the Northern Territory government has refused to legislate on smoking in public places, preferring to encourage such practices. Yet three other states already have passed legislation banning smoking in public places, and others are moving in this direction. At the very least, workers deserve to be protected from occupational exposure to the harmful effects of tobacco smoke, and legislation is the only way of guaranteeing this. In this regard, the Territory government's draft tobacco strategy includes the development of best practice model legislation, but it makes no commitment to enacting such legislation in a given time frame.

The promotion of tobacco products is another area that the Territory government has so far refused to act on. This means that tobacco companies are unrestricted in promoting their products through promotional give-aways and free samples. I understand that some of these activities extend to Aboriginal communities in the Territory. This lack of regulation is of great concern, especially given the much higher incidence of premature death from respiratory disease among Aborigines and the role that smoking plays in these diseases. Territory Health Services' own draft strategy notes that in the Top End of the Northern Territory over 80 per cent of Aboriginal men and more than 70 per cent of Aboriginal women smoke. Point of sale advertising is also currently unrestricted and, while the strategy talks about the necessity of eliminating these means of promoting tobacco products, the only commitment is to have completed a review of the legislation by the year 2001. While the NT dithers over a review, two states and the ACT have already enacted legislation.

In conclusion, it is time for the Northern Territory government to make a commitment to introduce legislation to reduce smoking and its harmful effects. It has already expressed its view that the mounting cost of public hospital care is unsustainable. With one in five deaths and one in 33 hospital admissions in the Northern Territory being smoke related, it is time for the NT government to do something more proactive and to use its own legislative capacity to reduce the burden that smoking places on the community. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Industrial Relations Commission: Meat Industry

talk.start.para: âAs the Senate would be aware, after a long and seemingly intractable fight Australia's waterfront is now operating efficiently to the benefit of our exporters, no less our primary industries. Given the history of the waterfront, what has happened is nothing short of a revolution. Likewise, an industry that took on all the characteristics of our old waterfront has also of late undergone an industrial revolution. The meat processing industryâor abattoirsâhave finally been given a chance to operate efficiently to the benefit not just of the abattoir owners but of farmers and exporters.

speech.para: Two events prompt me to make this claim. Firstly, one of Australia's biggest meat exportersâG & K O'Connor Pty Ltd, based at Pakenham, Victoriaâfollowing a year-long dispute and shutdown of its plant, has returned to work under improved employee productivity conditions. Secondly, it has been recently announced by a full bench of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission that the tally system will be removed from meat industry awards as part of award simplification in that industry.

The significance of these two events needs to be put in the context of the state of the industry. Like the waterfront, the processing industry had been subjected to report after report, ranging from the 1993 Booz, Allen and Hamilton report through to this government's 1998 Productivity Commission reportâall highlighting work practice inefficiencies, rorts, extortion and damaging strikes. Yet the industry is Australia's seventh-largest exporter, exporting approximately $3 billion a year, or approximately half its produce. The meat processing industry employs around 27,000 people and there are 75,000 Australian farms and properties producing livestock for slaughter.

The root of the problem is the abattoir costs. Figures taken from the Booz, Allen and Hamilton report show that, on a per kilo finished weight basis, the costs of our meat processing is uncompetitive. Australia can produce meat on a per kilo finished weight basis for 113c. In Argentina it is 105c, in New Zealand it is 72c and in the USA 41c. That therefore leads to the much quoted saga of the former restaurant chain, Sizzler, which decided to import US beef as it was cheaper than buying the Australian product. Even with the American beef being 60 per cent more expensive than our beef down at the saleyards, it was cheaper for Sizzler to purchase it in America, put it through their abattoirs, move it through their wharves, ship it across the Pacific, then across our wharves, past our meat inspectors and distribute it in their restaurants here in Australia.

For further evidence of the non-viability of our meat processing sector, we can use the export of live cattle to Asia as an example. Selling cattle live to Asia is more profitable. It is a poor indictment of our meat processing sector if processing cattle in Australia does not add value but subtracts it.

At the heart of the inefficiencies was the so-called tally system, a relic of the unions at the cost of employment and industry viability. In Victoria over the past 20 years, due to these practices, we saw abattoir after abattoir shut down permanently. The tally system, as I will explain, is enshrined in all the industry's awards, and it has ensured that penalty rates are paid after a prescribed number of cattle are processed. As the quota has not kept in line with the developments in the technology, maximum tally can now often be achieved after only four hours work: you meet your quota within four hours of starting work. Employers therefore are left with the choice of paying penalty rates for most of the working day or shutting the plant prematurely, in some cases after 30 hours per week. The tally system has often been described as the greatest obstacle to productive change in the industry. Therefore the commission's decision is a significant step towards improving workplace relations arrangements in the meat industry. It will encourage a productive and efficient workplace and provide focused wages and conditions for this very sensitive export sector of the economy.

As mentioned, the other significant breakthrough has been the return to work at O'Connor's in Pakenham. This has been a protracted dispute, which led to a lock-out of 350 employees in March this year. The dispute rested on the uncompetitiveness of the Victorian industry compared to New South Wales and Queensland, Australia's two biggest cattle producing states. It was estimated that the labour costs were $30 a carcass higher in Victoria than in its major competitors interstate. The absurd situation had been reached where it was commercially viable for interstate processors to buy cattle in Victoria and transport them to their plants elsewhere, thereby threatening Victoria's export capacity and ultimately the exodus of processing to other states.

However, a significant step in changing the culture of meatworks has been achieved through O'Connor's victory. This will have a cascading effect on all other meatworks in Victoria. It is worthy to note that throughout this dispute the Federal Court and the Industrial Relations Commission supported each step that O'Connor's took along the way. This was regardless of the rhetoric from the likes of Senator Carr, given on behalf of the union, when he addressed the Senate in about April this year saying that the lock-out was:
an attempt to put private profit before the livelihood of workers and welfare of many families in Victoria. If heâ
he was referring to Mr O'Connorâ
is successful, this will have broader implications for workers right across Australia.
Classic Senator Carr rhetoric. But the opposite is true. It is obvious that a viable meat processing industry supports the workers and the welfare of their families.

It is worthy to note that Australia faces very stiff competition from other meat exporting nations such as the United States, Canada and Argentina. Therefore, Australia needs to be continually improving itself so as to stay in the marketplace and, at the very least, it must rid itself of old practices and old union ways. The Productivity Commission report, Work arrangements in the Australian meat processing industry, which was released in October 1998, noted that Australia's share of the international red meat market has declined since 1996. Despite the world trade in beef and veal increasing by 30 per cent, over this period Australian beef and veal exports grew by only 15 per cent. Over the same period, beef and veal exports from the US, Canada and Argentina increased by 207 per cent, 201 per cent and 60 per cent respectively.

The Asian currency crisis is also depressing Australian meat exports to the regionâsuch is the international competition. Under this competitive pressure, there is no doubt that the industry has started to make strides towards efficiency gains. For the farmer, the two great industrial relations reforms initiated by this governmentânamely, the waterfront reform and the meat processing reformâwill facilitate a more efficient flow into export markets. It really does seem that this government's first wave industrial relations laws have truly brought a great and much- needed reform to this country, to the benefit of our standard of living.

talk.start.para: âTonight I wish to take a few moments of the Senate to discuss what I believe to be a defective republican modelâa model that people will be asked to vote upon on 6 November. Madam President, I pose the question to you, to honourable senators and to others listening to this parliamentary broadcast: would you knowingly buy a defective car? Other things being equal, of course you would not. Why, then, would anybody who values a stable democracy vote yes to a flawed republican model?

speech.para: The ideal constitution shows pathways to resolve conflict. It must not be a means of accentuating potential conflictâand this is what the model does. While the dismissal powers may be used, say, less than once in a centuryâor even moreâwe still need a constitutional model that is robust and will assist us in a time of crisis. The model on which Australians will be casting their vote is defective, and, in the event of a crisis, there will be a race as to whether the Prime Minister or the President can press the dismissal button first.

Does it really matter in the overall history of our democracy that we should wait, perhaps, another five years, rather than cast judgment on emotional issues or on issues such as that of a foreign Queenâwhose powers, I remind honourable senators and people listening to this broadcast, were effectively removed by both the Australia Act and the Statute of Westminster in the 1980s? I remind the Senate that Australia is fortunate to be one of a small group of democracies that have survived this 20th century. I urge everybody to think very carefully before casting their vote in the referendum on 6 November. I therefore urge you to vote no to that flawed republican model.

Aboriginals Benefit ReserveâReport for 1998-99.
Albury-Wodonga Development CorporationâReport for 1998-99.
Australia-Korea FoundationâReport for 1997-98.
Australian Communications AuthorityâReport for 1998-99.
Australian Prudential Regulation AuthorityâReport for 1998-99.
Australian Safeguards and Non-Proliferation OfficeâReport for 1998-99.
CentrelinkâSocial security compliance activity in CentrelinkâReport 1998-99.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Transport and Regional Services: Maritime Division Funding
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1225)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 5 August 1999:

question.para: (1) What level of funding has been allocated to the Maritime Division of the Department for the 1999-2000 financial year.
(2) Can a breakdown be provided of the funding for the Maritime Division.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) There is no longer a Maritime Division in the Department. As a result of a Department reorganisation, effective 1 July 1999, the logistics and maritime functions of the Department have been linked to form the Cross-Modal and Maritime Transport Division (XMT). This Division will improve the Department's transport focus across transport modes and foster the development of our trade facilitation and logistics approach.

The Cross-Modal and Maritime Transport Division of the Department has received an initial departmental cash funding allocation of $5.839m for 1999-2000. This is comparable with the 1998-99 level on the activities now undertaken in that Division. Activities and emerging issues will be assessed throughout the year to assess whether any Divisions of the Department require an adjustment to resources.

(2) The departmental funds are allocated to enable the Division to effectively contribute to the Department's delivering its relevant outputs to assist Senator Macdonald and me in pursuing our desired outcome for the community, Linking Australia through transport and regional services.
Cross-Modal and Maritime Transport Division contributes to the following output groups of the Department:
. Output Group 1 + Policy Advice and Ministerial Services,
. Output Group 2 + Regulatory, Investigative and Safety Services,
. Output Group 3 + Services to Communities
. Output Group 4 + Services for Industry and Government,
. Output Group 5 + Revenue Administration

The Cross-Modal and Maritime Transport Division also has primary responsibility within the Department for funds for administering the following maritime-related matters in 1999-2000 on behalf of its Ministers:
. Administered Item Group 1 + Services to Communities Administered on behalf of the Commonwealth
- Protection of the Sea (Air Pollution Compensation Fund) Act 1993 ($3m)
. Administered Item Group 2 + Services to Industry Administered on behalf of the Commonwealth
- Stevedoring Levy (Collection) Act 1998 ($24.980m)
- Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme ($56.4m)
- Bass Freight Passenger Vehicle Equalisation Scheme ($11.204m)
- Contribution to International Maritime Organisation ($0.270m)
The amounts shown in parentheses are current budgeted figures for those matters.

subdebateinfo.title: Child-Care Centres: Capital and Replace Upgrade Program Funding
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1241)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 12 August 1999:

question.para: (1) How many childcare centres have applied for funding under the Capital and Replace Upgrade Program.
(2) How many childcare centres nationally have received funding under the program.
(3) (a) Under which component was each grant approved; and (b) for what centre.
(4) What are the names and addresses of those childcare centres.
(5) In which state or territory is each of those childcare centres.
(6) How much funding: (a) has each of those childcare centres received; and (b) did each centre request.
(7) What has the funding been used for.
(8) Which of those childcare centres that received funding are: (a) community based; and (b) privately based.
(9) Which of those centres are (a) long day care; (b) multifunctional; or (c) disadvantaged.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Community Services has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) As at 1 September 1999, 73 child care centres have applied for funding under the Capital Replacement and Upgrade Program.
(2) As at 1 September 1999, 33 child care centres nationally have been approved for funding under the program.

(3) to (7) The answers to (3) to (7) are incorporated in the tables below. All child care centres, with the exception of two, received the amount of funding requested. The project components rejected for these services were outside the scope of the program.
(8) All centres are community based as the program specifically targets community based long day child care centres established by the Commonwealth and in which the Commonwealth has equity.
(9) All the centres are long day care centres. None of these services receives Disadvantaged Area Subsidies.
Capital Replacement and Upgrade Program

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 26 August 1999:

question.para: With reference to educational institutions that operate under the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991 and the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS):
(1) Can a list be provided of non-exempt, CRICOS-listed providers under the Act which are owned, operated or managed by providers who are or have been registered migration agents.
(2) Is it the case that under the Act, the department is required to conduct annual audits of tuition assurance scheme operator trust accounts by the end of each financial year.

(3) In regard to the recently completed departmental audits: (a) which non-exempt, CRICOS-listed colleges were not audited: (b) as at 25 August 1999: (i) how many of these do not have satisfactory annual audits, and (ii) what was the nature of the irregularities; and (c) as at 25 August 1999 what action has been taken in regard to providers who did not have satisfactory audits.
(4) How many students were enrolled in each college as at (a) 30 June 1998; and (b) 30 June 1999.
(5) (a) What are the names of all non-exempt, CRICOS-listed providers who have been suspended in the past 12 months; and (b) what was the reason for each suspension.
(6) How many previously suspended non-exempt providers are now seeking re-registration.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) DETYA does not hold details of the "owners", "operators" or "managers" of providers. The Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS) lists a provider's "Principal Executive Officer" (PEO).

Only one PEO is listed on the Register of Migration Agents maintained by the Migration Agents Registration Authority + Mr Kofi Ameyaw Osei of Caprock International Pty Ltd, trading as Lloyds International College, CRICOS provider number 01942A.
(2) The ESOS Act does not require Tuition Assurance Scheme (TAS) operators to maintain trust accounts, nor does it require DETYA to audit a TAS operator's account, trust or otherwise.

The ESOS Act does not require DETYA to audit a provider's notified trust account (NTA). The Act does require a provider to lodge with DETYA, a statement of NTA funds held on behalf of overseas students which must be accompanied by a report from a registered company auditor. The majority of providers are required to lodge their statement by 28 July each year.

(3) (a) The 128 providers listed in the schedule at Attachment 1 did not have their NTA audited by a registered company auditor because there were no overseas students enrolled during the reporting period or, if students were enrolled, they were in receipt of scholarships or paid their fees in arrears and course money was not required to be deposited into the NTA.

(b) (i) The following 26 providers submitted statements of NTA funds accompanied by a qualified report from their auditor or were otherwise identified as having failed to comply with one or more aspects of the financial and/or reporting requirements of the ESOS Act during the reporting period 1 July 1998 to 30 June 1999:
Australian International College of Business Pty Ltd, 01749B

Sydney International College of English Pty Ltd, 01554B

(ii) The identified instances of non-compliance were:
. failure to notify the Secretary of DETYA of NTA details + subsection 6A(6);
. failure to deposit course money into an NTA as soon as practicable + subsection 6A(1);

. failure to comply with the regulations governing withdrawals and payments from the NTA resulting in shortfalls to the amounts standing to the credit of students + subsection 6A(2) and regulations 4, 4A and 5;
. failure to comply with the refund provisions where a student defaults + section 6C;
. deposit of money other than overseas students' pre-paid course money into the NTA in contravention to the laws of trust + section 6A;
. incorrect particulars on the statement of NTA funds + subsection 8(1)(c).

(c) In accordance with subsection 8(2) of the ESOS Act, each of the above providers has been written to and asked to provide information in relation to the failure to comply with the requirements of subsection 8(1), and/or section 6A, and/or section 6C as the case may be. Each provider has been asked to provide evidence that the instance of non-compliance has been rectified and to demonstrate that there are arrangements in place to preclude similar instances of non-compliance in the future.
In the interests of natural justice, providers are afforded 14 days to submit their response.

As at 25 August 1999, only 3 responses have been received (none of the others is overdue). Evidence that instances of non-compliance have been rectified has been provided and, where required, providers have demonstrated that they have arrangements in place to enable compliance with the financial and reporting requirements of the ESOS Act in the future.
(4) (a) Refer to the schedule at Attachment 2.
(b) Refer to the schedule at Attachment 2.
