subdebateinfo.title: Australian Maritime Safety Authority: Homestead Technologies Inc.
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1365)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 30 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Has the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) communicated with the operator of the website domain, Homestead Technologies Inc. of Menlo Park, California, United States of America; if so, when and on how many occasions, did AMSA contact Homestead Technologies.

(2) Was the reason for AMSA contacting the above company to request that a website relating to the circumstances surrounding the loss of a fishing boat, the Red Baron, off the West Coast of Tasmania be removed.
(3) Prior to contacting Homestead Technologies, did AMSA seek legal advice on the contents of the above website.
(4) (a) Who provided that legal advice; and (b) what was the nature of the legal advice received by AMSA in relation to the above website.
(5) (a) When did Homestead Technologies respond to the AMSA communication; and (b) what was the nature of the response.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) AMSA has not communicated with Homestead Technologies.
(2) See answer to (1).
(3) Although AMSA management did not contact Homestead Technologies, it did seek legal advice on the contents of the website.
(4) (a) Clayton Utz.
(b) Publication of defamatory material.
(5) (a) and (b) See answer to (1).

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Department of Defence Preparation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1411)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 2 September 1999:

question.para: (1) What preparations have been undertaken to date in regard to the introduction of the GST on 1 July 2000.

(2) (a) What has been the total cost of those actions already undertaken; and (b) how much of these costs relate to: (i) consultancies, (ii) staff training, (iii) computer software, (iv) extra staff, (v) stationery, and (vi) other (please specify).

(3) Was the cost of undertaking this work included in the portfolio's 1999-2000 budget appropriation; if so, how was this funding identified; if not, what other area of funding has been used for this purpose.
(4) What future preparations are planned or expected to be required in regard to the introduction of the GST on 1 July 2000.

(5) (a) What is the total cost of the actions planned, or the estimated cost of expected actions; and (b) how much of the costs relate to: (i) consultancies, (ii) staff training, (iii) computer software, (iv) extra staff, (v) stationery, and (vi) other (please specify).

(6) Was the estimated cost of undertaking this future work included in the portfolio's 1999-2000 budget appropriation; if so, how was this funding identified; if not, what other area of funding has been used for this purpose.
(7) Is there expected to be any change in the ongoing running costs of the department/agency after the commencement of the GST; if so, what is the extent of the difference in costs.
(8) Are there any other GST-associated costs which the portfolio agencies will incur prior to the commencement of the GST; if so, what are those costs.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) A contract was let with PriceWaterhouse Coopers (PWC) to scope the potential impact of GST on Defence and to develop an implementation strategy. The scoping study, was completed on 7 September 1999 and included assessed impact on contractual, systems, policy, procedural and educational aspects and provided an indicative implementation costing schedule. The implementation strategy and project brief were presented to the Defence Executive on 6 September 1999. A Project team, tasked with ensuring Defence was GST ready by 30 June 2000, was subsequently established. The GST Project will utilise existing arrangements established for managing Defence's Y2K activities to enable synergies gained from the successful implementation of Y2K are carried forward into the GST implementation.
(2) (a) The cost to date of the scoping study is $260,000.
(b) The total sum relates to consultancies.

(3) The cost of undertaking the scoping study was not included in Defence's 1999-2000 budget appropriation; it was funded from Defence overheads. Defence will be seeking supplementation for GST implementation costs in the context of the 1999-2000 Additional Estimates. A detailed and robust estimated cost of GST implementation will not be known until all issues including system issues are resolved.

(4) The initial scoping study provided Defence with a broad understanding of a range of issues requiring consideration to ensure Defence is GST ready by 30 June 2000. The establishment of a Project team will enable the early overall definition of the scope of work required to enable a cost effective GST implementation.
(5) Whilst Defence has received an indicative implementation costs from the recently completed scoping study, a robust breakdown of these costs is not available at this time.
(6) See (3) above.

(7) Defence is unable, at this time, to determine the impact, if any, on overall running costs. It will take some time to complete a thorough and robust analysis. Defence's current priorities are associated with ensuring our major systems applications are GST compliant.
(8) See (5) above.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs Preparation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1416)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 2 September 1999:

question.para: With reference to the effect of the goods and services tax (GST) on the internal operations of the Minister's portfolio (that is, not relating to the services provided to the public), and in relation to each of the agencies within the portfolio:
(1) What preparations have been undertaken to date in regard to the introduction of the GST on 1 July 2000.

(2) (a) What has been the total cost of those actions already undertaken; and (b) how much of these costs relate to: (i) consultancies, (ii) staff training, (iii) computer software, (iv) extra staff, (v) stationery, and (vi) other (please specify).

(3) Was the cost of undertaking this work included in the portfolio's 1999-2000 budget appropriation; if so, how was this funding identified; if not, what other area of funding has been used for this purpose.
(4) What future preparations are planned or expected to be required in regard to the introduction of the GST on 1 July 2000.

(5) (a) What is the total cost of the actions planned, or the estimated cost of the expected actions; and (b) how much of these costs relate to (i) consultancies, (ii) staff training, (iii) computer software, (iv) extra staff, (v) stationery, and (vi) other (please specify).

(6) Was the estimated cost of undertaking this future work included in the portfolio's 1999-2000 budget appropriation; if so, how was this funding identified; if not, what other area of funding has been used for this purpose.
(7) Is there expected to be any change in the ongoing running costs of the department/agency after the commencement of the GST; if so, what is the extent of the difference in costs.
(8) Are there any other GST-associated costs which the portfolio agencies will incur prior to the commencement of the GST; if so, what are those costs.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The following answers cover the three agencies in the Immigration and Multicultural Affairs portfolio: the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA), the Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT) and the Migration Review Tribunal (MRT).
(1) Work undertaken to implement the GST in the portfolio to date includes:
. Establishing a high level Taskforce to guide, direct and coordinate implementation of the GST in DIMA, the RRT and the MRT;
. Evaluating existing revenues and expenses to assess the portfolio's exposure to GST, and specifically:
- which transactions constitute taxable supply;
- which transactions are GST-free, and which are input taxed; and
- which revenues could qualify for exemption in the Treasurer's determination under Division 81 of the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Act 1999;
Examining existing contracts that are expected to remain current at 1 July 2000, and therefore will be subject to transitional provisions.
. Evaluating existing financial and business systems to determine what changes are required to make them GST compliant.
- Begin developing a strategy for education, communication and staff training on GST issues and operations.

(2) (a) The cost of actions undertaken to date have been minimal + possibly less than $10,000 in aggregate. The work has been undertaken within the existing structures of the agencies concerned. Accordingly, the actual costs are not easily identifiable relative to other work undertaken by the agencies.
(b) (i) Nil
(ii) Nil
(iii) Nil
(iv) Minimal
(v) Nil
(vi) Nil

(3) Costs to date have been funded from the 1999-2000 Budget appropriation for departmental outputs for DIMA, the RRT and the MRT. These costs are small and have been accommodated within the existing funding provision for strategic planning, systems administration and resource management. No additional funding was provided in the 1999-2000 Budget to implement the GST in the portfolio.

(4) It is not possible to give a full list of tasks required to complete preparation for the GST within the portfolio until the actions reported in the answer to (1) above have been completed. Some tasks that have been identified to date include:
. enhancement to financial management and business systems;
. development and delivery of staff training programs;
. review of contracts to ensure GST compliance;
. revising cash forecasts and internal budgeting requirements.

(5) (a)-(b) It is too early at this time to report on planned actions to implement GST, and it is therefore not possible to estimate the likely cost. Many of the tasks that have been identified to date can be accommodated within existing funding by reallocating priorities.
(6) No additional funding was provided in the 1999-2000 Budget to implement the GST in the portfolio. All costs are planned to be met out of the existing departmental outputs appropriation.

(7) Under A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Act 1999 the Finance Minister is to issue directions on the application of the GST within Commonwealth agencies. It is not possible to determine the impact of the GST on the portfolio until these directions are known, however there is not expected to be any significant net change in departmental operating expenses following introduction of the GST.
(8) There are no known additional GST costs at this time.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Maritime Safety Authority: Red Baron Fishing Boat
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1424)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 9 September 1999:

question.para: (1) When was the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, or its legal advisers, first made aware of the existence of a website relating to the circumstances surrounding the loss of a fishing boat, the Red Baron, off the coast of Tasmania.
(2) When was the Minister, or his office, first made aware of the website.

(3)(a) When was the Minister, or any former minister, responsible for maritime policy, first made aware of the allegations about the circumstances surrounding the loss of the Red Baron and the resulting search and rescue effort contained in the website; (b) how were they made aware; and (c) what action did they take in response to that information.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (3) (a) The Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) first provided detailed advice to the then Minister for Transport and Regional Development concerning the Red Baron issues on 29 May 1996.
(b) The Minister was advised of issues relating to the Red Baron by way of a letter from the acting Chief Executive of AMSA.
(c) The Minister and former Ministers noted advice on this issue.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 15 September 1999:

question.para: In each of the past 10 years: (a) how many immigrants from Tibet have arrived in Australia; and (b) how many Tibetan refugees has Australia accepted.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Consistent with the standard classification of countries by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, people from Tibet are classified as Chinese nationals. The Department's movements and visa databases do not record ethnic or language data that would identify these people. It is therefore not possible to determine from the Department's systems (a) how many immigrants from Tibet have arrived in Australia; or (b) how many Tibetan refugees Australia has accepted.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 15 September 1999:

question.para: (1) (a) Is the Federal Government aware of comments in the preface to the British American Security Information Council research report, The Bug in the Bomb, by the United States of America (US) Ambassador Mr Paul Warnke that, "if the affected software involves nuclear weapons control systems, however, the consequences could be calamitous"; and (b) what is the Government's response to continuing concerns as to the Y2K readiness of the nuclear arsenals of the US and Russia.

(2) Does the Government disagree with the many prominent military advisers and academics, including Mr Bruce Blair, former launch control officer and now Bookings Institute senior research fellow and Mr John Pike of the Federation of American Scientists and the British American Security Information Council, warning of a "catastrophe", apocalypse" and "accidental nuclear war" because of inadequate Y2K preparation.
(3) What is the Federal Government's response to recommendations by the Canberra Commission that Australia request the US and Russia to take their nuclear weapons off hair-trigger alert.
(4) How many missiles do the US and Russia have on hair-trigger.
(5) How long does it take to after the insertion of launch codes for launch to take place on US Minuteman missiles and Russian intercontinental ballistic missiles.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) The Government is aware of the British American Security Information Council (BASIC) research report "The Bug in the Bomb".

(b) The safety of U.S. and Russian nuclear forces during the period of Y2K concern is a matter the Australian Government takes seriously, and we have sought advice from the U.S. and Russia about measures being taken to address this issue. The Nuclear Weapon States clearly have the greatest vested interest in ensuring that any potential problems are eliminated.

Two concerns commonly are raised about the possible impact of the Y2K bug on strategic nuclear forces. The first is the possibility of an accidental missile launch, and the second is that early-warning systemsâa key component providing confidence and stability between the nuclear powersâmight be affected.

On the first issue, the assessment of the United States is that there is "no risk of accidental launch" of its nuclear weapons. The U.S. is similarly confident that possible Y2K problems will not cause the accidental launch of Russian nuclear weapons. Procedures for launching nuclear weapons involve multiple levels of safeguards to verify and authenticate an order from, in the case of the United Sates and Russia, the President of the country. Computers by themselves cannot launch nuclear weapons.

On the second issue, the Government welcomes the announcement on 13 September by the United States and Russia on the establishment of a Y2K Centre for Strategic Stability in Colorado to eliminate any risk that a Y2K problem might arise in early warning systems. This centre will allow personnel from both countries to monitor early warning data on missile and space launches and also report on other potentially destabilising events which might be caused by Y2K computer failures, such as communications problems.

(2) The Government does not agree that preparations by the United States have been inadequate. The United States has spent some USD3.7 billion to ensure Y2K readiness across its entire defence operations, including its nuclear forces. There is less information publicly available on Russian preparations for the period of Y2K concern. However, for the reason's outlined above, the Government's assessment is that accidental nuclear launches caused by Y2K glitches are highly improbable.

(3) If Russia and the United States were to reach an agreement on the standing down of nuclear forces then Australia would, of course, welcome that. However, in order to maintain strategic stability, any such agreement would need to be
verifiable and enjoy the total confidence of both Russia and the U.S. For this reason, it is for the U.S. and Russia to address the merits of any stand down agreement.

(4) The U.S. and Russian Governments do not reveal the number of nuclear weapons on alert at any one time. Current aggregate numbers of strategic offensive arms held by Russia and the U.S. under the provisions of the Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty can be found at the State Department's Arms Control and International Security websiteâwww.acda.gov/factsheet/wmd/ nuclear/start1/startag. Not all of U.S. and Russian strategic offensive arms are on alert at all times.
(5) The U.S. and Russian Governments do not comment on this matter.
